<question>



How do u stop ''come down'' on pills?



I took some pills last night for the 1st time and now i have the so called ''come down'', my heart is racing and don't wanna even come out of my room!  how can i stop it?



</question>



<additional details>



I had to call in sick for work today as there was no way I would be able to face it, although I am feeling a little better - my heart beat has slowed down and I feel a lot more relaxed.



That was one of the worst experiences i have been through and i'm never gonna touch that dirty drug again!



Thanks for your anwers except for a few - i'm not trying to lose weight!!



The worst thing was I was clubbing untill 6am and then got home about 9am that's when it kicked it in - my body felt tired and wanted to sleep but my brain was 2 active!



</additional details>



<answer from>



dirty wrongen
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 1010 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



eat something healthy if you can. keep hydrated (dont overhydrate your self) chill out. dont worry. get some more kip. it'l be gone when you wake.



</answer>

Just rest, have something sugary/starchy to eat and keep hydrated. It will pass, don't do it again.

<answer from>



Erica Marie
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 180 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Take deep breaths.  Breath in deep for ten seconds, from your belly (you should be able to see it rise), then exhale.  Repeat this several times.  It should slow your heart rate down by 10 bpm.



Also, drink A LOT of water to flush your system.



Don't forget what this feels like, ok?  It is very dangerous.  There are great methods to lose weight; this is, by far, one of the worst.



You will be fine, though. :-)  Don't worry.



Hope this helps!
Erica



Additionally:  This is listed in the "Diet and Fitness" section, that is why we thought this was related to diet pills.



Recreational drugs can and will ruin your life. I know someone who has lost everything for the sake of getting high.  If you are at a club, try to challenge yourself by NOT giving in to what others are doing.  Show people that you can have a better time than them without drugs because you are cool like that.  Be confident in who you are, you don't need that crap.  Pills, alcohol, and weed will rob you of your personality and slowly transform you from who you were born to be.  There is nothing wrong with enjoying your youth, dancing, and friends, though!  All the best to you!



</answer>

<answer from>



Paul M
Member since: 27 September 2007
Total points: 2477 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



theres no way to stop it...your brain has used up all its serotonin in one big hit...which is why you prob felt so good last night...but now, it will take a few days for your brain to get levels back up.



you can try eating foods rich in the amino acid tryptophan which is one of the building blocks of serotonin...chicken, pasta, marmite etc etc.



failing that...go for a walk come back then sleep it off.



learn your lesson and dont do it again...they are bad news matey.



</answer>

<question from>



Tylers Mum
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What would you suggest to help me loose weight?



Sorry if this is alot of detail, im just after advice relevant to my situation.
My situation is:
I have a partner, and we have a 4yr old son. We've just moved to the area.



I weigh *gasp* 100kg, or 220lb i think it is.



Im 21, and 157cm short lol i've always been short, and always been curvy, but not fat.



I have 2 medical conditions, Benign Intracranial Hypertension and Poly Cystic Ovaries Syndrome. With the first one, i can't do hard or long exercise, or eat food with too many preservatives etc With polycystic ovaries, as is well known, it's harder to loose weight.
We live on the edge of town, too far to walk 'down the street' or to the shops etc There is no gym in town, or any weight loss centres. We have push bikes on layby for christmas. There are no walking groups around the area, and im not confident starting my own.
I'm getting married october next year. Its a casual wedding so i have the leniency of not having to book my dress 6 months in advance.



I dont know what size i'd like to be when i get married, nor do i have an overall goal weight. I weighed 70kg when i fell pregnant with my son, and its not like i've gotten taller lol
Unfortunately, we dont have much money, so i cant buy fancy food lol or cook elaborate recipes.
I dont smoke, or drink. we dont really eat take away cuz we can't afford it lol



I dont have a big appetite.
I dont like diets. I can't afford supplements.
Rather than a diet, I'd prefer a healthy eating and exercise plan that can also apply to my family.
I have an appointment with a dietician/nutritionist in a month.
I know my BMI. I know I'm overweight, obese even.
Im just after suggestions and advice.



</question>



<answer from>

Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 1252 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Do more exercise.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tamar H
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>

</answer>



<answer from>



gregyamk...
Member since: 08 April 2006
Total points: 15432 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Walking is the best for you right now so you're gonna have to get over your anxiety about starting a walking group alone. Walk in well-lit areas for safety and maybe go to a local school track and you'll meet other walkers as well.
Here are some good ideas:
1. Do something that gets your heart rate up a bit like, walking, running, biking, and swimming.
2. Eat Whole, Organic foods like: Broccoli, Cabbage, Organic Brown Rice, Beans, Spinach, Sweet Potato, Apples, and other fruits and vegetables in their Natural State.
3. Avoid eating corn, white bread, white rice, white potatoes, candy, sodas, chips, and anything else that you already know you shouldn’t be eating.
4. Drink clean water as your beverage of choice. Avoid Fruit drinks and fruit juices (unless YOU juice them yourself)
5. Stop smoking, drinking beer & wine, and drinking coffee.
6. Get 8 hours of sleep each night.
7. Hang out with people who want to be healthy.
8. Avoid anything with High Fructose Corn Syrup.
9. Look into taking a multi-vitamin.
10. Check out this website for excellent health advice: naturalnews.com



Tone up the muscles:



1. Join a gym and get a trainer.
2. If you’re short on cash, start a light stretching & yoga regimen.
3. Do push-ups, and light dumbbell curls for the upper body.
4. As I said above, walk, run, swim, and or bike
5. Take an aerobics class, a yoga class, or some other fitness class.
6. Join the local YMCA.
7. Buy or borrow this book by Bill Pearl called GETTING STRONGER.
In the book, he describes everything you need for a great fitness plan.
8. Crunches & Curl ups for the abs.



Mental Health:



1. Get a friend to talk to each day about your feelings.
2. If you have some money or insurance, get a counselor to talk to.
3. Learn how to meditate.
4. Join a support group for the issue you’re dealing with.
5. Ask your Higher Self (or God) for guidance.
6. Start keeping a diary or journal about your feelings & thoughts.
7. Write a ‘gratitude’ list every night.
8. Do something that makes you happy each day like: listen to your favorite music, draw, paint, write, or anything creative.
9. Do something for someone else who needs help.
10. If the above suggestions don't improve your mental health, talk with your therapist about the possibility of taking some medication.
11. Check out the book FEELING GOOD by David Burns.



Take care of yourself



Yam King



</answer>



<answer from>



ABSee
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Worry not! What you definitely don't need to do is to go on a diet. If you do, you will will lose weight, but there is over a 90% chance that you'll put the weight back on again.



To achieve permanent weight loss you need to 'change'...first to understand your current behaviors and then learn new behaviors. You do this by learning new habits...it's really not difficult to do.



I recommend you have a look at the Slim Habit (www.slimhabit.com). This is a weight loss system that will help you to learn 10 new slim habits. The program also includes a Personal Exercise Plan and lots of support. It's not expensive, there are no supplements or 'extras'.



I hope this was helpful...good luck!



Source(s):



www.slimhabit.com



</answer>

Martin R
Member since: 04 November 2008

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



when you start to feel stress try doing something else. exercise for example. It releases endorphins to your brain that make you feel good. It will help you feel a hell of a lot less stressed after exercising. I would suggest running, it will give you a runners high and would be a healthier habit. You can do it. you can do anything you set your mind to if you want it bad enough. And when you start thinking the negative thoughts, try to stop your self and think of something positive.

<answer from>



Hung C
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The key for losing weight is not difficult - consume less and workout more often - the problems surface when we really try to put that into practice! <answer from>



J Z
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 161 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everybody is different depending on their height, genes, and frame. You and your friend might be taller than most, hence weigh a little more. Or, you could be a little chubby at this stage in your life. You will grow taller and even out.



Without your height, I cannot determine what your BMI is, thus I cant tell you if you are normal or not.
My advice to you is to not worry about it unless you are severely obese (which I doubt you are). Dont starve yourself, it will only wreak havoc on your body. Exercise and eat healthy foods to stay in shape.



Hope I helped. If you have any more questions I'll be glad to answer them.



</answer>

John M

<answer>



The formula is simple.  Eat healthy foods, minimal starch and sugars, primarily protein and green vegetables.  Exercise 6 days a week, alternate weight training and aerobics.



The challenge is staying motivated.



Read books about exercise physiology.  Start with an old book by Covert Bailey called "fit or fat".  But read other authors and articles as well.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



Hi,
start counting calories. The simple plan is to eat less than you use. Consult a doctor and ask what calorie-level that is healthy for you (considering height, weight, bmi and other health-conditions you may have).



Start exercising aerobic or running or swimming. You need to work up your pulse -cardio workout is the fastest and most effective way to burn fat.



Cut carbs and fill up on vegetables instead. Weigh your food, try and find a good calorie-calculator online and start writing down everything you eat for a few days. Then it's easier to correct your diet and try to eat more healthy.



Drink at least 2 l of water a day. Water is essential, because if you are dehydrated in anyway, your body will retain water in all places of the body and that alone can make you feel bloated and chunky.



GOOD LUCK -you can do it!!



Good luck



Source(s):



http://www.wikihow.com/Lose-Weight-Fast



</answer>



<answer from>



soni
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 249 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you are able, aim to do at least 60-90 minutes of moderate physical activity on at least five days a week. (All adults should aim for at least 30 minutes on five days a week. However, 60-90 minutes is recommended if you are overweight or obese and are aiming to lose weight.) Moderate physical activity includes: brisk walking, jogging, dancing, swimming, badminton, tennis, etc. In addition, try to do more in your daily routines. For example, use stairs instead of lifts, walk or cycle to work or school, etc. See separate leaflet called 'Physical Activity for Health' for details.



Top tip - If you are not used to physical activity, try starting with a 30 minute brisk walk every day and then building up from there.



Special 'wonder' diets are often advertised, but they are often not helpful. This is because your old eating habits will usually return after a short 'special diet', and weight often goes back on.



Top tip - it is not usually a special diet that you need, but a life-long change to a healthy diet.



Drink mainly water



Many people use drinks full of calories to quench their thirst. Sugary drinks such as cola, tea and coffee with milk and sugar, milk, and alcoholic drinks, all contain calories. One of the easiest ways to cut back on calories is simply to drink water as your main drink.



Top tip - keep some water in a plastic bottle in the fridge. Chilled water is surprisingly refreshing.



Change of eating habits



Do you have any eating habits that can improve?



Are you eating larger and larger portions when you have a meal? Try to deliberately take smaller portions when you have a meal. Do not feel that you have to 'empty your plate'. Perhaps change the plates that you have in your cupboard (which may be large) to more medium sized plates. In this way you will naturally serve up smaller portions.



What do you have for snacks? Try changing chocolates or cakes for fruit.



Do you have second helpings at meal times when you are really already full?



Skipping meals is usually a bad idea. It sounds a good idea, but many people just become hungry, and have snacks later in the day, and eat too much at the next meal. Eating at regular mealtimes may be a first important change. Three healthy meals a day is best.



Do you always have a pudding? Will a light yoghurt do instead of a sweet pastry?



Do you eat quickly? Are you ready for a second helping before most people have half finished their first plateful? Obese people, on average, eat faster than non-obese people. It is best to train yourself to chew each mouthful for longer, and to eat slowly.
Top tip - three healthy meals each day, including breakfast, is better than skipping meals. Eat slowly, chew longer.



Planning what you eat



It is important to plan ahead. Perhaps you could plan each day's meals and recipes the day before. In this way you will know exactly how much food you will be eating. This is better than looking in the cupboard and fridge before mealtimes or snacks to see what is there.



It is best to separate eating from other activities, as this helps to you keep to your planned eating for the day. So, try not to eat whilst on the move, whilst watching TV, during meetings, etc.



Top tip - plan tomorrows eating today.



Lifestyle change for life



To lose weight and to keep it off, it is vital that you are motivated, really want to lose weight, and want to improve aspects of your lifestyle. Some people lose weight by strict dieting for a short period. However, as soon as the diet is over, they often go back to their old eating habits, and the weight goes straight back on. Losing weight, and then keeping it off, needs a whole change of attitude and lifestyle for life. This includes such things as:



the type of foods and drink that you normally buy.



the type of meals that you eat.



your pattern of eating.



the amount of physical activity that you do.
Top tip - ask family or friends to help and encourage you to keep to a healthy lifestyle.



Be realistic



What is your goal weight? Many people aim to get down to a 'perfect' weight. This is often unrealistic and may never be achieved. If the weight that you aim for is too low, you are likely to become fed up about slow progress, and give up. To lose 5 kg is good. To lose 10 kg is excellent. (10 kg is about one and a half stone.)



Top tip - in most cases, most health benefits come from losing the first 5-10% of your weight. This is often about 5-10 kg.



VISIT U E ONLINE NEWSPAPER FOR CURRENT HEALTH NEWS AND COMMENTS!



</answer>

<answer from>



saved_by...
Member since: 21 September 2006

</answer from>



<answer>



I have had this operation and can tell you that it does not make you gain weight. The gallbladder does not store all the fat out of your food either, you must have misunderstood.



The gallbladder is a small pear-shaped organ that sits under the liver on the right side of the abdomen. The gallbladder concentrates and stores a greenish-brown liquid called bile that is made by the liver. When a person eats food, the gallbladder contracts and sends bile into the small intestine through tubes called bile ducts, where it helps break down fats in the food.



</answer>



<answer from>



a s h b e e
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 964 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i have had my gallbladder removed.
the reason he is taking it out is to not cause problems,
i asked him if there was a specific diet to follow, & he's like nope, that's what we removed it for !
i mean, yuo should eat healthy anyways.
i've just noticed when i eat fatty foods, or anything that the gallbladder would digest slower, goes through me quicker.
like if yuo eat somehitng like mcdonalds, you'll probably get the runs.
because it won't take long to digest, because it doesn't go through your gallbladder anymore.
i just get the runs when i eat greasy food, which is something i barely do because the runs isn't fun. haha..
but sometimes i treat myself to some rotten ronnies.
the only fast food that hasn't given me the runs is burger king.
but yeah, just watch what you eat. you just have to eat a bit of everything to see what your body will do with it.
& how not having yuor gallbladder will react to it.
get to know your system all over again. haha.
like i said, for me, it's greasy foods.



i haven't gained weight from it, or lost weight from it.but do remember everybody is different.

<answer>



if you are going to the gym as much as you say you are and are eating right then the only 2  reasons that I can think of is that you are probably either plateaued or you are losing body fat but also gaining muscle weight. Stop looking at the scale and start looking in the mirror and if you can see that your body is changing for the better then leave it be. If you feel you have plateaued then try this workout and diet.



~1 ½ cups high fiber cereal with 1 cup of 1% or 2% milk or soy milk of your choice add ¼ cups of blueberries or strawberries



~ 1 cup of low-fat cottage cheese with a piece of whole grain toast ¼ spoon of cinnamon and ¼ spoon of splenda added



~ 1 cup low-fat yogurt with ½ cup of berries of your choice mixed in along with a piece of whole grain toast with peanut butter.



~ 1 c. whole grain pasta with small grilled chicken breast tossed in a fresh basil extra virgin olive oil



~ 1 grapefruit with 2 tsp. splenda and a slice of whole grain toast with 1 tbsp. peanut butter



~ 1 cup of steel-cut oatmeal with ¼ to ½ cup of frozen mixed berries and ½ cup of cottage cheese



~1 Scrambled egg / or two egg whites with very light cooking spray and any veggies of your choice and a slice of whole grain toast with 1 tbsp. of peanut butter



~ 1 Weight watchers bagel of choice with 2 wedges of laughing cow



cheese or low fat cream cheese with sliced strawberries and 1 tsp. splenda



~ 3 Wasa crackers with 3 tsp. of peanut butter and a med banana



~ Wheat wrap with turkey and light mayo slice of tomato and a piece of romaine lettuce



~ ½ cup of raw baby carrots, ½ c. of sliced and peeled cucumbers with light ranch dressing



~ 1 100 calorie pack of smart pop popcorn



~ 1 fresh and peeled pear cut in half with 2 tsp. of light mayo and ¼ c. of 2% shredded cheese to go on top



~ ½ c. hummus (homemade if possible) with 1 c. of fresh veggies



~ 2-3 slices of fresh low-sodium turkey breast, 1 c. of seedless red grapes, ¼ c. of walnuts or almonds, and a stick of 2% cheese of your choice



~ 1 serving of whey protein



~ 1 serving of casein powder/ Syntha-6 from GNC



~ 1 South beach protein bar



~ 1 Fiber 1 bar



~ grilled chicken breast, 1/2 c. of brown rice, ½ c. steamed broccoli



~ grilled salmon, ½ c. brown rice, and 1 c. steamed zucchini and squash combined



~ baked flounder, ½ cup of brown rice, and 1 c. of steamed veggies



~grilled lean steak with grilled portabello mushroom caps and a side romaine salad



~hamburger on a wheat bun with light condiments and all of the veggies you can handle on it



~ 1 c. raisin and 1 medium apple



~ 6 oz. of boiled shrimp, 1 c. whole grain pasta, ½ c. steamed broccoli and 5 sprays of smart balance butter



~Grilled chicken breast romaine salad with your choice of good toppings (include some type of nut)



~ Imitation crab meat salad with your choice of toppings



~ 1 apple and three graham crackers with a tbsp of smart balance peanut butter



~ Peanut butter and low sugar jelly sandwich



~Baked ham steamed cabbage and carrots



~ Oat bran bagel with cream cheese, 6 oz. of low fat yogurt and cantelope



~ 1 c. of high fiber cereal and 1 medium banana



~1 med. banana ¼ c. almond 1 c. yogurt (mix together)



~1 large sweet potato with ½ cup of  cooked oatmeal and 4 oz. of grilled chicken



~ Acai berry juice 4-5 times a day along with one to two cups of oolong tea ( wu-yi tea) a day ( helps with belly fat and energy levels to raise metabolism)



TIPS



Add any fresh herb to any dish to rev up the flavor or add 1 tbsp. Ms. Dash to rice or fish and poultry to give it a zing. You can even add some cajun spice to just about anything if you like it hot. There is an also fresh squeeze of lime and lemon that takes the food to a tropical place. Don’t be afraid to mix and match your dishes as long as you stay within your counts for that meal and for that day. Remember that you need to eat for what you have coming up not for what you have already done. Say if you know you are going to take a nap after a meal then don’t eat so many carbs because you will not be burning them off.



do all of these for 60 seconds for 1 set and 5 minute warm up stretch and 5 minute cool down stretch with a 30 second rest in between. and you should stay tone and muscular while helping to burn fat. They are separated into 3 days. then do some cardio in between those and make sure to get plenty of rest and eat plenty of protein and carbs. If you do all of this, then you will need to increase your caloric intake as well. hope this helps and if you have any questions about the workout then email me. p.s. to keep lean muscle this workout uses body weight and no more than 10 lb. weights for men and 5 lb weights for women. If you are a beginner then try 30 seconds and rest for 10-15 in between the workout.start with 30 seconds for beginner and rest for 10-15 seconds. The entire workout lasts 25-28 minutes when done at the full 60 second time. Mix in c



Source(s):



ISSA-CFT  Certified Fitness Trainer
shannon_du@yahoo.com



</answer>

<question>



Is 126 lbs ok for a ten year old girl?



My Friend and I were being weighed in Gym the other day. When we were exchanging weight i asked her much she weighed and she said 126 lbs. She said that she thought she was really fat and she was embarrassed. I just wanted to ask on here just to assure her she is not in any danger...is she?



</question>



<additional details>



She is about 4'11



It's Been atleast a month and a half since she was last weighed, she plays softball so i don't know how much she is at right now



</additional details>



<answer from>



mandyspl...
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 704 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



She's a little overweight, but not by much. The best way to calculate whether you are underweight, normal, overweight, or obese is by calculating your BMI (Body Mass Index). http://www.nhlbisupport.com/bmi/



She's at a 25.4. The normal weight calculation is 18.5-24.9.



Just reassure her that she looks fine and pretty. Try exercising together. It's a lot easier to lose weight when you have close support.



</answer>

<question>



Why am i hungry when I'm not?( i know i already asked but i put the question in the wrong section)?



When im at school about an hour before lunch i always get really hungry and my stomach starts to growl. I started eating a little more for breakfast and it went down a little but this didn't happen before. I eat dinner really early ( like 4) and i think that might be the reason. is it?

Dinner- 4

<answer from>



Vegan_Mo...
Member since: 18 April 2007
Total points: 9461 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you're not hungry, then why are you hungry? Usually, when my stomach feels empty and it's growling, then I know I'm hungry. Most mornings I'm done with breakfast by 7:30. Usually, by 11 again, I'm hungry. I don't always get to get a snack then if I'm caring for my daughter, but I know I'm hungry. Yesterday morning, I was hungry again by ten, so I had a banana. By 11 I was hungry again (I did give a small part of the banana to my daughter with her breakfast), so I had a slice of whole wheat bread with some Smart Balance. I didn't get to eat my all natural PB sandwhich with all-natural fruit spread until a couple of hours later, after my husband and went to vote and we stopped to drop off our health insurance papers. Had I not had anything at ten, thinking I could wait or thinking, "Gee, even though my body is telling me I'm hungry, I can't possibly be because it's not lunch time yet," I might have just passed out somewhere along the way, as it was at least five hours until I was able to have lunch.



However, this is just me and my body. You could be different.



</answer>

Stacy

<answer>



Yes, push ups will work out the entire upper body (to a degree). Mainly, though, push ups help increase chest strength. Triceps are also targeted, especially if you try a closer hand positioning.



Source(s):



Been lifting weights for 22 years.



</answer>



<answer from>



Maldavi
Member since: 14 April 2007
Total points: 7262 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Standard push-ups generally work the pectoral (chest), triceps, and outer forearm muscles.  Also utilizes the abdominal & lower back muscles to some extent (used to keep your body straight while doing the push-ups).



</answer>



<answer from>



sumyoung...
Member since: 20 February 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on how u do ur push up.  With hands close to ur body it will build your body, it will build triceps.  With arms at chest level shoulder length apart it will build your chest and triceps.  It doesn't help biceps.

Between going to classes and working, I don't exercise much....so, is it kind of a no-brainer that I'm depressed and have low-esteem lately? Will changing my eating habits have a considerable impact on my depression/anxiety? Also, I've been diagnosed with anxiety disorder, but maybe it's the caffeine from all the pop?

<answer from>



J Z
Member since: 05 October 2008

<answer>



I would think so. If you eat poorly, your body will feel bad, and be weighed down by it. Exercise releases endorphins, which make you happy. So yes, Body feeling bad + no exercise= depression.
Try to drink water instead of the pop (no diet soda either)
For breakfast, have something healthy and lite, like a bowl of granola with low-fat milk, banana, and maybe a little honey.
For lunch, try a whole-grain sandwhich with no mayo and lean meat, like turkey or ham. Have a fruit and maybe a snack like a healthy granola bar with your lunch.
For dinner, (grilled) chicken ceasar salad with lo-fat dressing, or whole grain pasta with tomato sauce and a side salad with lo-fat dressing, or a bowl of brothy soup(quite low in calories, but watch out for the sodium)
To get some exerxise, start small. Walk a little extra, do a few situps or pushups and jumping jacks when you wake up. Walk up the stairs. Remember you have to look for oppurtunities to exercise!'
I hope this helped



</answer>



<answer from>



Vegan_Mo...
Member since: 18 April 2007
Total points: 9461 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's quite feasible. I've read things about the correlation between poor health choices and mental health. However, I eat very well and I have been feeling bummed lately. That's just due to my current life circumstances. Anyway, I know people who eat poorly and continue to complain about how they feel, physically and mentally. I've also read that even diet soda is not very "diet" in terms of health. (There is something in the November issue of "Prevention" [I looked for it on the site, but didn't see it; Perhaps the library has a copy] and from the December 2007 issue of "Experience Life" http://www.experiencelifemag.com/issues/... )



I think it makes sense-- The body runs on real food as the body is real and whole. Given artificial junk and the body reacts negatively.



Being surrounded by food isn't necessarily a bad thing, but if you're going for the white bread, the meats, the fried stuff, then it's bad. Also, if you don't just want water, squeeze a lemon or two in it, that might be of some help.



I think that changing your habits will have a positive effect, even if you don't exercise much. (I have worked restaurant and I don't remember getting to sit much.)



Do a search for "nutrition and depression" and see what you come up with. I'm thinking of the Dr. Andrew Weil site, but I don't know what it is, just do a search.



Also, the holistic health section might have people who could help you as well.

<original file>2660.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk115714.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Kev J
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I workout with my Dumbbells everyday, is that safe?



</question>



<answer from>



Stacy
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 603 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you work don't work out the same body parts every day, then it's fine. Like, if you work out chest on Monday, then work out a different muscle the next day.



Source(s):



Been lifting weights for 22 years.



</answer>



<answer from>



cookiecu...
Member since: 07 September 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you might strain your muscles skip to every other day



</answer>



<answer from>



Maldavi
Member since: 14 April 2007
Total points: 7262 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



As long as you're not putting an undue strain on your body, (ie, working your arms to total failure).



If you work the dumbbells until your arms feel tired, but not "dead", then it's ok to do it everyday.  If you're working your arms to exhaustion, then you need to allow a day or two of rest in between sessions to allow the muscles to heal.



</answer>



<answer from>



debratna
Member since: 16 April 2008
Total points: 4169 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question>

Source(s):



abs:
http://www.bodybuilding.com/fun/abwork.h...



</answer>



<answer from>



JH&lt;3CN
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



do crunches.
http://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=2mQs7nM6Y8...



</answer>



<answer from>



Deeje
Member since: 16 April 2008
Total points: 2175 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sit ups aren't great for the abs. They also cause a lot of tension on your back that can mess you up down the road.



The absolute best ab exercise is the crunch. There are two types of crunches, and the one I'll tell about now is the best for toning abs. This method will also take fat off your stomach faster than you'd believe.



Lay on your back with your feet underneath something for support, such as a kitchen counter or even your bed. Place both hands under your head with your elbows pointing up. (Make sure they stay that way throughout the exercise)



Now, keeping your lower back straight, lift your head all the way up until your elbow reaches your knees. What you want to do is touch your right elbow to your left leg, and then slowly recline back so that your head is on the floor again. Now do the same process again, this time touching your left elbow to your right leg.



This left-to-right rotation is what really tones the lower abs and sides. Do as many of these as you can possibly push yourself to do, and then add five more. :)



</answer>



<answer from>



selphie1
Member since: 21 October 2007
Total points: 3229 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Running can help with lower abs but the best moves you can do for those are reverse crunches and planks.



</answer>

My suggestion is to just avoid meat and animal products and to eat however much you want of whole grains, fruits, veggies, beans, etc. and avoid anything with enriched flour, corn syrup, high fructose corn syrup, artificial flavors and colors and anything that looks as though it was created in a lab by man and not in nature by God. That's what I do, and at six feet, 155 pounds (give or take five, probably more give) it's worked for me. I don't consider it a "diet" in the pop culture sense of the word, but how I choose to live. The one thing I don't do, that I wish I did do, is exercise. My heart would be a lot healthier and happier, though I probably would be skinnier. Eh. <question>



Is it ok to take a multi-vitamin and a Super B-complex at the same time?

<answer from>



kgarther...
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



These are fine to take together. Absorption is not effected. These vitamins are water soluble and anything you do not use will be excreted.

Steve P
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 916 (Level 2)



</answer from>

Multivitamins are low in all vitamins because they are formulated to work in a synergistic way together. There is no problem taking a Super B Complex at the same time.

Randy B
Member since: 29 December 2007

<answer>



First of all, a person that is hungry should eat. No one should starve themselves, but rather eat good, healthy food to lose weight. Drinking coffee with the meal is not bad, unless it's before bedtime. Try to limit your caffeineated drinks to none 3 hours before bedtime. Coffee is great in the morning as it helps jumpstart metabolism and helps get your day going. Coffee is also a dieuretic and in some people it has a laxative effect. I'd say no more than 4-5 cups a day though max.

<answer>



I think the 1st 2 questions are BS... Anyway you diet plan looks good, you're getting just about enough calories. But it also depends on how much you used to consume and how much less you're consuming and how much you're losing working out. Just remember 3500 calories is equal to 1 pound. So if you're consuming that much less a week + losing them through your workouts you can lose 1 pound a week. If you want to lose 25 pounds thats 25 weeks. But if you cut your calories by 3500 a week and yyou're burning like 1500 a week in your workouts thats a pound and a half a week and it will take you about 19 weeks.. You can get the idea now :) Good luck!



</answer>

armoredm...

<answer>



If you could keep that up it would certainly loose you weight. But the question is, can you keep it up for the 70ish dayishs it would take for you to lose that weight? If you can, that's great, but think about maybe taking every 3rd day off from your diet and breaking even in calories that day.



Also, crunches give you a pretty belly, but they don't burn that many calories. Keep in mind when losing weight you want to focus on calories most.



Oh, and to get the 70ish days. I'd guess a 5'1 woman would burn about 2350 calories doing what you're doing (maybe more, depending on your day today life). There are 3500 calories in a pound of fat, and your diet and exercise would keep your metabolism up. So I did 25(pounds) / ((2340ish - 1150ish)\3500).
Okay sounds great, but keep it up!

<question from>



duckie
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can I control my binge eating? have you ever been to therapy for an eating disorder?



I literally can't stop eating. I go into a frenzy and just raid my kitchen.



I have tried associating food with an emotion but i can't seem to find a connection with any particular emotion. I have tried several diets, all of which have failed miserably.



I am sick of the guilt I feel after eating. I hate that I can't control myself...I'm not too overweight....YET!!!!



has anyone heard anything about hypnosis or counseling to treat this? any tips or suggestions?



thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Clarice S
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A friend of mine uses an Acai Berry product, it flushes all the waste out your system.



Shes lost quite a lot of weight and she swears by the stuff. She got it for free too, only had to pay like $5 shipping.



Here's their site: http://tinyurl.com/acaiberry500



</answer>



<answer from>



Sammy G.
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 1714 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i'm actually a "recovered" anorexic who went into a pretty serious spiral of binge eating while "recovering"... and i still do it sometimes, which is terrible.



i have heard of counseling to treat it, but it tends to be more helpful in cases where there is a real underlying emotional problem (e.g. abuse).  what i'm doing (and it's slowly been working for me- but note- it DOES TAKE A WHILE to work) is literally recording EVERYTHING that goes into my mouth.  i'm sure you've heard or read that before, but i find that recording EVERYTHING, especially on binge days, helps me to really stop on think when i'm about to go on a binge ("the last time i did this i ate _____ calories, half of them were in bread! i don't even LIKE bread!" that kind of thing).



it's a lot easier to stop yourself if you know you'll feel guilty writing it down later.



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk116765.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Gabe
Member since: 05 January 2008
Total points: 5855 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



Mental Health



</question from>



<question>



Please tell me how to not get hungry and to avoid over eating when i do get hungry?



could you please tell me ways to where i wont get so hungry that i over eat? whenever im hungry i tend to keep eating, how can i stop? thanks.



</question>



<additional details>



It did. I have mental health issues and i know for certain when i get stressed or in a mood swing i start to eat. how can get to the root of this problem and solve it already? yes ive been to counseling, thereapy, psychiatric hospitals, medications, the works, and it hasnt worked.



</additional details>



<answer from>



strooxst...
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 157 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Good question.



The problem is that you've stretched your stomach to the point where you cannot get that "full" feeling until you eat a lot of food.  The solution is to shrink your stomach.  Yes, this can happen, and without surgery or a clamp inside of you.



Some people skip breakfast, and end up eating 2 large meals every day.  You end up becoming like a camel, storing up food for the rest of the day, stretching out your stomach to fit all that food in.



I eat 5 or 6 meals a day, but when the sun goes down, I've eaten the same amount of food as anyone who eats 2 large meals.  It is hard to get started, because at first the smaller meals won't give the "full" feeling, but after a while, your stomach shrinks, and you end up feeling satisfied more often.  Also, it speeds up your metabolism and makes your body store less energy as fat.



That's the physical side of things anyway.  Mentally, there is no quick fix.  You must have the willpower and determination to want to lose weight.  No one can give that to you but yourself.  So if that's the real issue, stop asking for help, you're wasting your time.  Instead try and find some way to reward yourself.  Take up a sport you really love, or go out and LARP instead of playing table top games, whatever you can find that you're passionate about that will keep you active.  I was a huge anime fan and loved Jet Li movies, so I took up martial arts.  Then you can stop focusing on your weight and start focusing on getting better at your activity.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



leahpant...
Member since: 25 January 2006
Total points: 163 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When you eat meals (bfast/lunch/dinner or snacks) make sure you eat fiber and protein. Fiber and protein help fill you up on less food and keep you fuller longer. Try snacking on whole wheat pretzels or whole wheat Goldfish. With breakfast try scrambled eggs with whole wheat or whole grain toast. For dinner, or lunch, eat brown rice instead of white rice.



If you need to eat processed food look for things that have a lot of fiber in them. Look for Soluble & Insoluble fiber - these will determine how full you will feel.



However!!!!! Drink a lot of water. Switching suddenly to a high fiber diet may cause some gastrointestinal problems (constipation for one) so make sure that you slowly introduce high fiber products into your diet over the course of three or four weeks. Let your body adjust and drink lots of water. You may be able to do it faster but listen to your body and snack smart. Eat more fruits & vegetables, too they are great sources of natural fiber, sugar and protein.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



for your poll answer NO.
however, do be careful bc this may cause you to relapse. is it possible for you to see a dietitian? this helped me with my past ED.'s. the very same happened to me but then, it stabilized with discipline. your body is not used to allowing food to live in you for a long period of time and is storing it for a "just in case" scenario. your body is smart. however, you do need to stabilize your eating. even stable eating may cause you to gain weight, but it will eventually stabilize as it gets used to food being a part of your daily life. esp. being mia, your body is storing massive amounts of fluid. this too will stabilize if you maintain healthy eating patterns. remember this, the more you go back and forth btwn eating healthy and reverting back to ED you will tend to be a heavier adult bc your body is retaining what it can to survive. as i said, your body is smart and has to use its defense mechanisms to survive.



i hope you can get with a dietitian and a therapist to deal with the root issues of your eating. we can eat right, but as long as those feelings that trigger us to revert are there, you will continue this destructive pattern of eating behavior. this compulsive eating is just another manifestation of an ED..
i hope you find peace and health.

<answer>



Exercise is of course always the key to looking AND feeling absolutely gorgeous!  It's great for complexion and overall health.



A few changes to the diet will also help to improve how one looks and feels.  Cutting out (or greatly reducing) sugars, saturated fats, hydrogenated oils and processed foods (anything from a can, a box, or a fast food place) can help to lose a few unwanted pounds safely and quickly. Increase daily water intake to half of your weight in ounces.  You will notice a change within two weeks.  Not only will you look great, but your energy level and confidence will soar.



Make sure to eat a healthy breakfast to jump start your metabolism for the day!  And try to eat something healthy at least every four hours during the day to keep it going.



There are some detox diets out there that can produce the same results, but be sure that if you go that route to choose one that seems more logical and less drastic.... if it seems unnatural... it probably is.



Good luck and have a great time at your event!



</answer>

<original file>4084.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk117296.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Kev J
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 118 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do i get a strong back like this? (Pic Included)?



http://www.menshealth.com/media/images/c...



</question>



<answer from>



WestCoas...
Member since: 08 June 2008
Total points: 3266 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A complete back workout should consist of working 4 areas on the back..



The lats(for width, the 'wings' of your back), traps( the big muscles visible on either side of your neck, from the front view, which also run down either side of your spine, to the middle of your back), your rhomboids (the muscles around your shoulder blades), and your lower back (to give that 'christmas tree' look to your lower back, and to support a strong, healthy back).



The pic you posted has all these muscles developed to a good level.  here's what you need to do to get the same.



Lats:



Wide-grip pulldowns.  3 x 8-12



Underhand pulldowns(closer grip). 2 x 8-12



Traps:  Barbell/Dumbell Shrugs:  4 x 8-12



Rhomboids:  Barbell/Seated Cable Rows.  4 x 8-12



Lower Back:  Hyperextensions  3-4 x 8-12



This is a compete back workout, and can be done all together in the same workout.  Use weight that is heavy enough to do the number of reps required.  If you can do more than 12, up the weight.



Allow a month to two before you expect to see any significant improvement in your back muscles, visibly, anyway.



You can do this workout a maximum of twice a week, with at least 2-3 days rest between sessions.



Source(s):



I'm a Personal Trainer.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank You =)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Digital Age
Member since: 06 November 2007
Total points: 7311 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The width of your back depends on the width of your shoulders and narrowness of your hips. those are genetic factors.
Beyond that, you can strengthen and enlarge the back muscles by cable rows, bent over rows, dumbell rows, one arm rows, wide rip chinups behind the neck, etc..
Don't overlook deadlifts.



</answer>



<answer from>



Braiden P
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lat pull behind your head
Miltary Press(When you sit straight up, and lift the barbell above your head, always do about 10% less then your incline.)
Pushups! Do 3 types Wide, narrow, and the Diamond!



Chinups will really help your back.
and Dips =]
good luck



</answer>

<answer>



Lots of protein.  Eat a snack or a small meal every 3-4 hours.  Like maybe half a sandwich and a piece of fruit.  But make sure you get protein every time.  And no junk food at all.  You'll be surprised how hungry you DON'T get because it keeps your blood glucose level stable.

<original file>10491.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk20549.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



!!!! BIGGIE!!!!!
Member since: 23 January 2008
Total points: 2 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



When you get your biceps cut won't it also get your shoulders cut?



you know that line difined line that cums in ur shoulders between ur biceps an triceps wen ur built?...how do u get that cut line...i was thinking that if i jus build my biceps an triceps i cud get it now is that true?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



The only way to put muscle mass on your biceps and triceps is by consuming more calories than you can burn, and by resistance-training.  If you want them cut, you have to burn more calories than you take in.  You can't get cut and put on muscle mass at the same time, it is physiologically impossible.



And, you can't specifically get your biceps or shoulders cut.  There is no such thing as spot-reduction, where you can get rid of body fat from a specific area in the body.  You can only reduce overall body fat.



A thumbs down? I suppose what all the research and scientists have shown are wrong then?



</answer>

<answer from>



Cari
Member since: 18 April 2008
Total points: 282 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Frankly, I don't think there really is a best weight loss pill because I don't think they work long term - long term they help you gain weight because the weight loss is unsustainable.



Ok... so you're thinking only about december - but that's a relatively short time in the history of your life - don't do something now that messes up your metabolism in the long term and changes your body composition so that you'll find it much harder to maintain and lose weight after you've used them.  Besides this whole idea of diet pills 'working' is one that fascinates me..... in my opinion.....



* If you can't maintain the weight loss without following the regime forever, it hasn't worked.



* If it restricts, deprives or tells you what or when to eat - you aren't living naturally and it hasn't worked.



* If it hasn't freed you from a fear of regaining what you've lost - it hasn't worked.



* If it hasn't helped you work out the underlying issues for why you were eating - it hasn't worked.



* If it hasn't helped you to think of exercise as something to enjoy - it hasn't worked.



* If it hasn't helped you fall more in like with yourself even if you have lost weight - it hasn't worked.



* If it hasn't freed your from a dieting mentality - it hasn't worked.



*It it hasn't left you with making healthier nutritional and exercising choices because you 'want to' and not because you 'have to' - it hasn't worked.



*If you still think of food and your body as enemies instead of friends - it hasn't worked.



*If you still fear the scale - it hasn't worked.



Source(s):



http://www.ditch-diets-live-light.com/di...
http://www.ditch-diets-live-light.com/bo...



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Help....Exercise question?



hi
i was wondering ....
when you go cycling does that just help tone up your legs or will it work all over your body?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



If your bike is adjusted properly you should get a total body work out.



with the exception of shoulders and arms.



I really recommend cross training.



cycling and swimming really compliment one another ... or cycling and modern dance moves to music if a pool is not available.



Source(s):



retired p.e. teacher.



</answer>

<answer>

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Elaine W
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 6699 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Women's Health



Other - Health & Beauty



Pain & Pain Management



</answer from>



<answer>



Rice is healthy as long as it is cooked properly as it can be a breeding ground for bacteria. You must make sure you eat it piping hot or straight from the fridge. Before cooking make sure it is thoroughly rinsed to get rid of some of the starches and bacteria.

<original file>1160.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk21781.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Kate
Member since: 16 March 2007
Total points: 21 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Which yoga exercises helps you to feel motivated and strengthens your immune system?



Any ideas?



</question>



<answer from>



Olo B
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 364 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Any form of strenuous exercise will make you feel motivated.
A good healthy diet will strengthen your immune system.



Twisting your body into various shapes will have little if any benefit.
Simply biology will always triumph over "fashionable" and "spiritual" hobbies.



Ofc continue Yoga if you enjoy it... but don't delude yourself into believing it has amazing health benefits.



</answer>



<answer from>



SMPC
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yoga is known for its amazing power to boost the systems of the body. A good yoga workout massages and nourishes every single organ in the body. Each cell is caressed and nourished.



Yoga helps lower stress hormones which can compromise the immune system, while also conditioning and giving love to the lungs and respiratory tract. The lymphatic system is strengthened and toxins are swept away. You may notice that you get far fewer illnesses when you have a regular yoga practice.



Personally, I haven't been sick this year at all. I have been a little surprised just how well I have been. I do have a fairly high immune system, but normally I would have had a minor cold or at least a moment of feeling under the weather by this time of year. This year... nothing! Just great health!



So what I have I done differently? I always take vitamin C and Zinc... this year and last year. I have been eating more immune system boosting super foods, but somehow there seems to be more to the story...



Last year I was doing yoga once a week, but it has only been this year that my passion has lead me to practice as often as possible and really see what happens when you twist your body into mad positions on almost daily basis.



Recently, I had a slight sore throat. The next morning as I walked to my Ashtanga yoga class, my nose was definitely dripping a little bit. When I stepped into class, I needed a tissue and I was a slightly concerned that my practice might be tricky with a cold brewing.



By the time I got to triangle pose (about 20 minutes)... there was no dripping nose whatsoever.



I left the class feeling fantastic (as always)... and realised that the cold had totally disappeared. And I haven't had one symptom since! In fact, I am once again feeling above average in my health, which when I think about it is a definite improvement from last year.



I practice in an Ashtanga yoga class and lately we have been in a small room with lots of heaters...so the sweat is dripping (not the nose.) I can't imagine the amount of toxins and germs that must be forced to exit the body through the sweat glands.



More than ever, I am convinced of the incredibly powerful effect that yoga can have on our immune systems and overall wellbeing.



1. Downward Dog Clears the Sinuses and and congestion.



2. Tortoise and Shoulder stand stimulate the Thymus gland to boost the immune system



3. Camel Pose and Backbends flush out the lungs



4. Corpse pose and Child's pose give the body a chance to integrate the postures and provide deep healing.



</answer>

Christin...

<answer>



It honestly depends on how much of it you eat.  If you reduce your overall caloric intake, you will lose weight.  If you increase it, you gain.  It's pretty simple.  With that said, choosing those two foods is not a healthy way to lose weight as they don't have much in the way of nutritional value and you'll probably cause other health problems by doing that.



The other thing to consider is that mac and cheese is high in calories so you will have to eat less of it than many other foods you could've chosen to meet your reduced calorie intake.



</answer>

<asker's comment>

<answer from>



Allison
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your meals do sound healthy and well balanced. Make sure to mix up what you eat every day though so that you don't continually eat the same thing. Eating the same "healthy" meals every single day turns out to be unhealthy in the end.



Try looking at http://www.mypyramid.gov/index.html for an idea of what really makes your mealplan healthy. It is all about balance and getting the right amounts and enough of each food group. That ensures that you get all of the vitamins you need to be healthy and all the calories you need for energy.



Good luck staying healthy!



</answer>

<original file>12691.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk22993.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Annika
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What happens when you get too much, or too little fiber?



Can getting alot and/or not enough fiber bad for you?
What effects will it have on your body?



</question>



<additional details>



It's for a school project, so what does it do more to your insides. I know a little about it that it can cause constipation. But what else?



It's for a school project, so what does it do more to your insides. I know a little about it that it can cause constipation. But what else?



AND, does fiber work well with other nutrients?
If so what ones, and why?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Lamar's Alarm
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 24214 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Alternative Medicine



Women's Health



Men's Health



</answer from>



<answer>



too much fiber - loose stool.



too little fiber - consipation.



</answer>



<answer from>



gogreenl...
Member since: 31 December 2007
Total points: 1938 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The optimal fiber intake should be 25g for woman 30 for man.



If you eat too little you will have constipation, a slowing of the intestinal tract. That results in very few or unproductive bowel movements.
Too much fiber or too much all at once can cause gas, flatulence, abdominal pain, or diarrhea.



Shoot for 5-9 grams with every meal and a few snacks like apples or bananas.



</answer>



<answer from>



CuriousG...
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 229 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The big deal about fiber is getting enough to keep your bowels moving.  I'm sure there is a lot of other benefits, but I don't believe all of it.  Some say cleaning your bowels can stop cancer, etc etc, but then they say that isn't proven at all either and just bowel rinses trying to sell products.  But, it is good to get cleaned out.



</answer>



<answer from>



Run_For_...
Member since: 28 January 2006
Total points: 2152 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>



Try my diet i am a 17 year old female who weighs approximately 50 kilos and I am 168cm in height. I go to the gym three times a week for an hour of cardio (mainly on the cross trainer) and according to the machines i burn about 850-950 calories each time. ( i know the machines aren't that accurate).
My daily diet is ;
Breakfast: all bran with semi skimmed milk and 2 pieces of fruit ussually nectarines. (300 calories ish)
Snack: apple (50 calories)
Lunch; turkey sandwich (whole meal break and turkey slices no spread) (150 calories)
Snack; will bar (213 calories)
Dinner; varied but consists of 300 calories. tonight i had a fish cake, green beans and noodles.
Dessert; 250 calories..maybe and icecream or yohgurt and bar
Supper; cereal with semi skimmed milk (allbran or special k) with a piece of fruit (250-300 calories)



I drink two litres of water each day and i have about two diet drinks and two cups of green tea.



good luck xxxx

<answer from>



Ash
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 424 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



120 pounds is not a healthy goal for 7 months.  People who loose between 0.5 - 2 pounds a week are the most likely to keep it off long term, so you should aim for that.  7 months is approximately 30 weeks, so could realistically aim to loose 60 pounds over 7 months, still a large accomplishment!  I'd make a chart and track your weight and measurements weekly so you can actually see the progress.  You need to get rid of 1000 calories each day to loose 2 pounds a week.  You could do that by eating less / better and doing some cardio work.  Building muscle doing weight training will help too since muscle burns way more calories than fat even when your just sitting around the house.



Good luck to you!!



</answer>



<answer from>



ny
Member since: 10 February 2008
Total points: 55317 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



When  losing  weight,  you should follow the dual course: exercise and
diet  together.  If  you exercise without dieting, you will get bigger
appetite,  which  will  lead  to  increase  of  weight, or muscle grow
underneath  the  fat  layer, and make you bulkier. If you diet without
exercising,  you  will  become  flabby  and will have excess skin. For
diet,  go  wheat  free.  No pasta, pizza, bread and so on. And no food
after  7  p.m. People achieve marvellous results with it. Depending on
your  initial  weight, you can drop upwards from 20 pounds a month. If
you  don't  eat  wheat then you don't eat all those sticky, fatty goey
cakes,  you  don't eat junk food, and you don't eat biscuits. But your
diet  is  still  balanced.  It  costs  nothing, and you do not have to
calculate  points  or  to  buy special meals or plans. For exercising,
start with walking, and then switch to running/jogging. Running is the
most efficient and calorie-burn exercise ever. If you are overweight a
lot,  walk  first  or you may have health complications (heart attack,
disjointed  bones and so on) For targeting your problem areas, check up
these  Workout  Exercises  :  Weight Training, Plyometrics , Stretches
(Flexibility),  Pilates,  Ball, Cardio Dumbbells, Cables etc. 100's Of
Exercises.  They  have animated photos, so it's easy to understand how
to do them. http://www.myfit.ca/exercisedatabase/exe...



</answer>



<answer from>



donorbyh...
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 194 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<original file>13000.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk23338.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



tom r
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 89 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the quickest/fastest way to get a 6 pack?



I have decided i am going to work out and was wondering if anyone had any ideas for the best way to get a 6 pack?



</question>



<answer from>



Dan
Member since: 10 May 2008
Total points: 18645 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Sit ups: Please note that sit-ups can be a strenuous activity on the lower back. Understanding how to get a six pack and not damage yourself in the process is critical. Do not strain yourself; build up this type of exercise slowly. Twisting during this exercise (left elbow to right knee) is NOT effective and put the lower back under tremendous stress. If you feel even the slightest twinge, then stop.



In order to strengthen your abs, care and technique are necessary. Effective sit-ups need to pull the torso towards the knees from a lying position only using the abdominal group of muscles. If you have your legs straight on the floor then more powerful muscles in the legs will do most of the work.
To counteract this you should bend your knees while sitting up and so make the abdominal muscles feel the burn. If you gather a momentum you will not be working the muscles effectively. Only by slowly raising and lowering will you achieve the best results.



Leg lifts: The challenge with this exercise is to keep your legs straight and not to let your feet touch the floor.



Lie of the floor with your hands by your sides. Keeping your legs straight lift them to 90 Degree and back down but to do allow then to touch the ground, repeat back to the 90 degrees position.



Jacknife Sit-ups: Discover how to get a six pack the hard way with this intense workout.
Start as you would in the position to do sit-ups with your hands at your sides.



Without bending your knees, simultaneously lift you legs in the air and your head and shoulder so that your whole body makes a V-shape. If you can manage it the try to touch your toes.



Then relax and go back to the starting position.



V-ups: This exercise requires good balance and strong core muscles. It can be performed on a bench but can also be carried out on a mat on the floor(but don't let those legs touch the floor).
Bending your knees, simultaneously lift your legs and your torso so they form a V as you can see from the photo. Then go back to the relax position, during this exercise you arms should remain horizontal.



The Static hold: Get into the push-up position but with your forearms touching the ground. Make sure your body is a straight line from your shoulders down to your toes and hold that position for a minimum of 1 minute.



This exercise strengthen your core abdominal muscles. Repeat this exercise more and more as you strengthen the core muscles.



Understanding how to get a six pack through strengthening your core muscles is key to achieving great abs!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



cheers



</asker's comment>



<comments>



Dan



Good luck!



</comments>

<answer from>



ellieee .
Member since: 25 February 2008
Total points: 1804 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's some weight loss tip's:



- Exercise 6 to 7 days a week.



- And try to break your workout into two different sessions, this gives your metabolism a jolt.



- Drink 6 to 8 cups of water a day. And try to drink ice cold water, it burns more calories.



- Take enough vitamins, especially ones that promote weight loss (such as 1800 mg. of Fish Oil, Vitamin B Complex, Co-enzyme Q-10, ect. Do your research).



- Drink green tea or take green tea pills ( it's been shown to speed up your metabolism).



- For your metabolism's sake, eat within 1 hour of waking up and don't eat 3 hours before you go to bed.



- Try a vegan or vegetarian diet (it worked for me :D).



- Drink 12 oz. of warm lemon water (use the juice of 1/2 a lemon) with a little sea salt every morning. This will detoxify your body and make your skin look amazing.



- Or, if giving up meat just isn't your thing, just count calories. Try to have around 1200 a day.



- Try to avoid white, bleached, or enriched flour.



- Stay away from high fructose corn syrup and hydrogenated oils.



- Eat every 2 to 4 hours to keep your metabolism going.



- Eat 5 to 6 small meals a day to keep your metabolism up.



- Try to get 6 to 8 hours of sleep. When your body is deprived of sleep your appiteite increases by 15%.



- Sugar and artificial sweeteners are the devil. If you have a sweet tooth, grab some fruit.



- Avoid all junk food, fast food, and fried food.



- Try only drinking water, tea, and black coffee. There are so many hidden calories in drinks.



- Eat whole grain foods and healthy fats (like olives, avacados, nuts, ect) and stay away from refined or "bad" carbs.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You are a fantastic size from the sound of it! The average weight for a woman is 165 lbs and average height is 5'4". You are a little bit shorter than average, but your weight is much lower.



If you are concerned about looking great in your dress, adding a little tone is the best way to do it. Just 30 minutes a day, or at least every few days can really make a difference. If you exercise, your weight might actually go up, but don't be alarmed! Muscle weighs more than fat, but will look sleeker in your dress.



Congratulations on your upcoming marriage, and focus more on that great new husband you will have rather than the numbers on a scale. The way he feels about you is far more important than that.

<question from>

<question>



I have a lot to lose.. where should I start?



I have a lot of weight to lose (about 80-100 lbs) Where should I start? I don't want to get to overwhelmed but I'd like to make some changes just a little at a time. Any suggestions would be appreciated. Thank you.



</question>



<answer from>



Shell
Member since: 01 November 2006
Total points: 4185 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You just need to dive in head first. CUt out "white" foods like bread, pasta, rice and sugar. No sweets, soda, or fried foods. Eat lean meats and protiens like chicken, fish, beans, and eggs. Eat 5 small meals a day instead of 3 large meals. Eat lots of veggies and fruit and not so much meat and dairy. Look at lables. Last but not least, 30-60 mins of cardio a day and some light weight training will make all the difference. You can start off walking, it will be easy on you. Use light dumb bells (5-12 lbs) and work your arms, do crunches, and if you can get a gym membership talk to a trainer. Good luck!



</answer>

<answer from>



Gatorgir...
Member since: 16 October 2007

</answer from>



<answer>



I too had this problem.  I have since dropped 98 pounds.  I joined Weight Watchers.  It is a great program that still allows to you to eat normal food, not special products.  It teaches you the steps you need to follow to drop the weight in a safe manner and to keep it off.  I went from a size 24 to a size 12 in about 10 months.  It allows you to still have the foods you love, just not necessarily as much as you had before (ie macaroni and cheese, ice cream, etc).  It also helps because there are no "off-limit" foods and I was never hungry.



Source(s):



www.weightwatchers.com



</answer>

<answer>



Unfortunately you cant just lose fat off one area (without liposuction which cannot be done on your face!)

<answer from>



BananaMa...
Member since: 10 June 2007
Total points: 1585 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok your dimples are not disappearing for no reason. Your body is storing excess energy as fat in your facial area. The fat storing order is different from one person to another. One might get fat around the waist first while some get fat in their face first and then other areas respectively.



To avoid this you need to maintain a diet that is sufficient for your daily calorie requirement. Anything excess will show up in your face. Exercise will help too but that's too much work right ? Some people choose the balance between both.



</answer>

Contributing In:

</question from>



<question>



A questionn about net carbs...?



i read this
net carbs - Net carbs are determined by subtracting those carbohydrates that have a negligible effect on blood sugar levels from the total carbohydrates. Examples include fiber, glycerin & maltitol, which may or may not be listed on the label. Example: If the label reads: Total Carbohydrates 20g, 15g Sugar Alcohol, 1g Dietary Fiber. Subtract Sugar Alcohol and Dietary Fiber. The effective carb count is 1g. (20 –15 – 1 = 4).



soo when i eat something w/ fiber or sugar alcohol im not really getting all the carbs in me?? what does this mean exactly



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



http://lowcarbdiets.about.com/od/product...



"By definition, fiber isn't digested in the small intestine and so isn't broken down into glucose and absorbed into the blood."



"If I was going to advise people to avoid a single ingredient in "low carb" products, it would be maltitol. The other sugar alcohols range from a little to a lot better than maltitol, with erythritol being the best"



hey i wasn't sure either. but i always made sure to eat lots of fiber lol.



</answer>

<answer from>



Michael R
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi,



I'm no nutritionist by the way, but I did read somewhere about daily calorie count and calorie count per meal. You know, the total for males is 2,500 calories, 90g fat, 310g carbohydrate to maintain a healthy weight?



Well, there's also a guideline for how many calories you should eat "per meal", and I think this is where a lot of people fall down and gain weight.
Some info here: http://www.vhi.ie/hfiles/hf-461.jsp , the Irish health insurance website, comparing the "full Irish" or "full English" breakfast to your daily limits!



I'm sure medical organisations or nutrition websites have thresholds for calorie intake per meal.



If I was to guess, since breakfast essentially "kick-starts" your metabolism for the day, 600kcal is loads.



Guess it all depends if you want to eat 3 square meals, or snack mid-morning...



</answer>

Rhianna

Contributing In:



Women's Health



Other - Health & Beauty



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm afraid that is not a realistic target! Your not going to lose 100 pounds in a month!



Weight loss is a simple input and output balance, if you eat more calories than your body burns up in a day, you will gain weight. To lose weight, you need a healthy reduced calorie diet and daily vigorous exercise. Less in, more out
You should be looking to lose on average 1-2lbs a week.



Source(s):



RN



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr Frank
Member since: 03 February 2007
Total points: 92727 (Level 7)

A realistic level of weight loss is 2 lb a week and few people sustain that long term. You might lose a half stone in a month if you work at it using both diet and vigorous exercise.

<answer from>



davidjam...

<answer>



Go see your family physician for a checkup and ask if you're at a healthy weight. Don't try and guess that on your own. Regardless, ask about herbal methods to reduce or eliminate bloating that are safe for children. Do not use celebrity photos or videos as a healthy comparison for your body type. Do not trust your peers or any unschooled family members to give you safe and sound advice on this important health subject. Know that even if it turns out you need to lose fat that you are still an attractive young lady.



If your physician supports it, consult with a professional nutritionist and lifestyle expert or seek out their media. Be highly selective and avoid all fads, whatsoever. If you need to lose weight, an adult can usually only lose about two pounds a week safely, your rate is probably less. Make a healthy plan. Most of all, BE REALISTIC.



</answer>
