<original file>2419.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk25217.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Maddie H
Member since: 28 December 2007
Total points: 1363 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Elderly diets - what to include/exclude?



Doing research on diets for elderly people.



What food groups should be included and excluded, and why?
Also, what effect would this have on their body?
Would they be lacking in any nutrients/vitamins?
And any certain nutrients or vitamins that should be included?



Thanks x



</question>



<answer from>



Ginny Jin
Member since: 23 February 2007
Total points: 33081 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



They usually don't like spicy food.They prefer bland, easily served things like Macaroni cheese, Shepherd's pie, fish pie etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



mrsd
Member since: 06 July 2008
Total points: 1015 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Many elderly are on special diets-low sodium, diabetic, for example.
See if you can go to a Nursing Home during meal time and observe what is served and how it is served -is the food chopped up for those who don't have teeth? Is salt on the table? Are some people fed? The dietitian at a nursing home may welcome you to interview him/her



</answer>



<answer from>



Rhianna
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 18996 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Women's Health



Other - Health & Beauty



</answer from>



<answer>



Like everyone they will need a balanced diet which includes their five a day, calcium as they get older will be a good thing, the main problem with the elderly is dehydration, the elderly associate drinking fluids with going to the toilet more frequently, which sometimes due to immobility is a problem. It's always best to keep foods simple with the elderly, often as they get older they are less able to tolerate highly spiced and fatty diets (which really should be avoided anyway). Try and stick to a low sodium diet (to be honest this is general advise for ALL age groups, we all should do this.



Actual Vitamin D and calcium supplements are a waste of time for the elderly, it's better to include calcium it in their diet.



Source(s):



RN



</answer>



<answer from>



Rim K
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



if u wana loose weight at home without dieting and exercising
by just changing your eating habits
u can refer to
http://medifastweightlose.blogspot.com/
and u ll find so many tips for weight lose n medifast detox diets
try them n loose weight easily



</answer>

Contributing In:

<answer>



It's unlikely this will be of much benefit. For effective weight loss, you need a healthy reduced calorie diet COMBINED with daily vigorous exercise (60-90 minutes daily) Either on it's own is unlikely to make much impact. Weight loss is a simple input and output balance, if you eat more calories than your body burns up in a day, you will gain weight. Your not getting the balance right. Less in, more out!



Your exercise regime sounds fine by the way.



Source(s):



RN



</answer>



<answer from>



trueblue...
Member since: 29 November 2006
Total points: 681 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



A specific diet does not work for everyone. Each body/metabloism is different. I believe you need to find your body type and follow that diet, or your blood type and follow that type of diet.
My sister went on a low calorie diet and lost a lot of weight over a 12 month period. She felt great following that type of diet. I tried her diet and it did nothing. Yeah, sure I lost a few kg's in the beginning, but then I just stopped. Felt crappy all the time, headaches, etc....
I read a very good book called Eat Right For Your Blood Type. I followed that diet (and still am) and I feel excellent. I have reached my ideal weight and have maintained it for the past 18 months. It was very difficult at first because a lot of the foods that my blood type should avoid, were of course all my favourite types of foods. But I just made adjustments and have reaped the benefits.
I really think this is the best way to lose weight and stay healthy. Give the book a go. It's very well written and makes sense to me!
Hope this helps you



Source(s):



personal experience.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rim K
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



if u wana loose weight at home without dieting and exercising
by just changing your eating habits
u can refer to
http://medifastweightlose.blogspot.com/
and u ll find so many tips for weight lose n medifast detox diets
try them n loose weight easily



</answer>

<question>



How much weight can I lose?



Okay, I started out at 283 lbs (any rude or mean-spirited answers will be reported, so don't waste my time or yours) and anyhow, since I've changed my eating habits (not dieting, because this is a permanent lifestyle change) and exercising by walking an hour a day in the park, I'm down to 272 since like, a week ago. I've been keeping a diary of what I eat every day. If I continue to eat like this and take a brisk 1-hour walk every day, how fast should the weight start coming off? What's the maximum you think I can lose per week and also, any opinions or advice would be nice as well. Here's what I'm eating.



9/23/08
B: Medium banana, water
L: SlimFast Optima 190 calories
D: small salad with 3 cherry tomatoes, italian dressing
one slice of whole grain bread (no mayo) with 1 tbsp of tuna salad and 2 leaves of lettuce, caffeine free diet Pepsi, water
Oh, and 2 white russians which does have milk (skim) and coffee liquor



9/24/08
B: half medium banana, caffeine free diet Pepsi
L: SlimFast Optima 190 calories
D: Salad from subway with turkey breast, olives, green peppers, cucumbers, tomatoes and fat free italian dressing... 2 bites of Lydiah's sub that she didn't eat (wheat bread, mayo, turkey, cheese) and 2 slices of apple, water, water, water



9/25/08
B: medium banana, water
L: SlimFast Optima 190 calories
D: one slice of whole grain bread, tsp Hellmann's spicy mustard (5 cal's) with 1 tbsp tuna salad, 1 leaf of lettuce, salad w/ 3 cherry tomatoes, italian dressing, small handful of Baked Lays, water, caffeine free Diet Pepsi



9/26/08
B: small gala apple
L: SlimFast Optima 190 calories
D: one small slice of Little Caesars pepperoni pizza, water, a few white russians



9/27/08
B: small gala apple, 1 slice whole grain toast (no butter), water
L: SlimFast Optima 190 calories
D: salad with 3 cherry tomatoes, 5 slices of cucumber, 1 slice sandwich turkey (chopped up), italian dressing, small baked potato w/ tsp. butter, water, water, water



9/28/08
B: None
L: water, SlimFast, half medium pear
D: small salad w/ 2 cherry tomatoes, italian dressing, small baked potato w/ tsp. of butter, half of a small hamburger steak, water, caffeine free Diet Pepsi, water, water



9/29/08
B: small pear (it's kinda nasty about right now)
L: SlimFast Optima 190 calories
D: one can Campbell's chicken noodle soup, 5 saltines, one slice whole grain bread, tsp Hellmann's spicy mustard, one slice turkey breast, one slice cheese, caffeine free Diet Pepsi, water, 2 white russians



9/30/08
B: Small handful of dry Honey Nut Cheerios, water.
L: Slimfast Optima 190 calories
D: small salad with 4 cherry tomatoes, one slice turkey breast (diced), sprinkle of bacon bits, italian dressing, bowl of chicken soup with egg noodles, 5 saltines, caffeine free Diet Pepsi



</question>

<question from>



メロン

Total points: 159 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do you make your biceps bulge?



i want to make my biceps bulge without flexing



what are the exercises that can make this possible



please reply ASAP



i want to start today



</question>



<answer from>



benw2200
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 867 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



lol..



flexing is what makes them bulge. the only thing that will make your biceps more noticable is to work them out. Do curls and stuff to make them bigger- also do tricep workouts, because if your triceps are bigger they'll push your bi's out and make them look even bigger than they are.



Big arms are a result of hours of hard work in the gym, so get in there and get to work.. there is no ASAP magic method.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



true man true



thats what im gonna do



ill spend more time and effort im the gym



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Dom S
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 428 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Want to know the reason(s) why some people look like they have "buldging biceps w/o flexing?



1) They work out regularly and their Bicep and Tricep Bracii are taunt from it and Hypotrophed ( enlarged)



2) They have a low body fat so there is less " protective skin" on top of the muscle, so you end up getting more of a buldged look.



Ok, so you are doing these things ( working out and burning fat) but you want to offer the illusion of having " Buldging Biceps "?



It is as simple as a wardrobe switch



Start wearing tighter shirts.  If you are normally a large, go down to a medium.  If your abs havent caught up then wear a tank top Underneath it ( tucked in to keep excess from showing)  If the shirt is too short... put it on the floor, step on the shoulders and grab the bottom with your hands.. now lightly, but firmly stretch the material.. Don;t worry, if it is cotton it will give...... Put it on and leave it untucked and POOF!!!  you have the illusion of sleeve stretchign biceps until your workout regimen catches up.



Hope this helps :)



Source(s):



ACE Personal Training Certification



</answer>



<answer from>



Jeff G
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unless you already have decent sized arms, and just need sometihng to boost vascularity, the best advice I can give you is to start putting on more muscle, and eventually the size of your biceps will always be noticable to everyone.



Also, do not overlook the TRICEPS!!!!!! The triceps are visibly much larger, and make up 2/3 of the visual part of the region. You should never focus on just one muscle group, as this will make you look foolish rather than cool in the eyes of those whom it really matters.



OK.........here's probably the answer you would have wanted to hear from the very beginning:



NITRIC OXIDE BOOSTERS



These will help your muscles pump up quickly after just a few exercises, and the pump will last for quite a while after you've gotten your blood pumping!



</answer>

Also, the area under my breasts..like the 'first ab' - the area on top of bottom of my lungs-  i find really hard to tone. I know how to tone my stomach area etc, but i just can't seem to tone the part above my actual stomach

</question>



<answer from>



Luciana L
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi, it is commonly acknowledged that fad diets fail over 90% of the time. I suggest that you go on down to http://snipurl.com/3v985 its a superb website with lots of free help and advice. I shed 8 pounds in three weeks by taking their advice



</answer>



<answer from>



cleancoa...
Member since: 01 March 2007
Total points: 4127 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bent over rows help upper back your elbows should be parallel to shoulders. Try shrugs with the weight held behind your back.  Cable rows are als extremely helpful, again for upper back, keep your arms abducted to 90 degrees, try to pinch shoulder blades together when exercising. 5 sets, low weight. Negatives 2X as long as positive.



The upper part of the six pack: suck stomach muscles in then do crunch.  1 set, to fatigue--good burn



</answer>

<question>



I'm an ideal weight, but still fat (PICTURES INSIDE)?



I started my weight loss in February 2008, i have lost 5 stone (70 lbs) in 9 months.



- I'm a male
- 20 years old
- I now weigh 10 stone 12 pounds (152 lbs)
- I am 5"9 tall
- According to BMI websites, i am the ideal weight for my height



- I do at least 30 minutes of exercise per day (walking, jogging, cross-country machine)



- I do weight training every 2 days (dumbbells, flys, bench press, push-ups, squats)



- My diet is very good, i eat 5-6 small meals per day and have been very successful



------------------------------



I'm very happy that i have lost so much weight in only 9 months, but I'm slightly disappointed that my body is still far from perfect. My man-boobs are still quite big, so i don't have the confidence to wear t-shirts in public that often - My stomach is still not flat, I'm not sure whether it's fat or excess skin (?) Also, i have fat/skin on my back, which stands out.



What should i do? Should i cut down my cardio? Because i don't want to be underweight and skinny. Please help me out guys!

<answer>



Sometimes body shape is just genetic and even though you are a healthy weight you carry "pockets" of fat in certain areas, which are "problem areas", now i don't promote surgery as a solution for weight problems, but if you are saying you do all these things and still have these pockets of fat, then it may be that liposuction would be a good choice for you. Toning will help so keep doing abdominal exercises such as crunches and sit ups.



BTW i am just a stay at home mum, i am not a surgeon or an affiliate of anything but i have seen cases like yours before where only lipo has worked.

me

<answer from>



IAN L
Member since: 15 July 2008
Total points: 440 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to adjust your attitude to food and/or yourself. There are phycological reasons for this sort of behaviour but I'm not qualified to comment on those. What I will say is try to think of food as fuel (this is helped if you exercise - as suggested above). Food should not be viewed as a drug or punishment nor used to alter your mood.



If you binge through hunger - then try to sort out a decent diet that doesn't leave you starving and make sure you have something healthy to hand like carrots.



</answer>

<category>

</category>



<question from>



Maria L
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 189 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Running and walking?please help?



so my sister and I started a plan that we were going to go exercising so we started going to the outdoor track and walk and lap run a lap till we get to two miles and we went on Sunday night and we were feeling pretty sore Monday so we decided to go on Tuesday night even though we were still pretty sore.But for some reason we woke up this morning feeling less sore then we did the night before....why is that? shouldnt we feel even more sore because we pushed ourselves?? could it mean that its not working????



</question>



<answer from>



Hil J
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



if u wana loose weight at home without dieting and exercising
by just changing your eating habits
u can refer to
http://medifastweightlose.blogspot.com/
and u ll find so many tips for weight lose n medifast detox diets
try them n loose weight easily



</answer>



<answer from>



HollyHob...
Member since: 31 August 2008
Total points: 910 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You're feeling less sore because it IS working. Your bodies are getting stronger.



Push yourself just a little bit more each time. For example, run 1 1/2 laps, then walk one lap. It's important to strike a balance between pushing yourself and overdoing it. It's good to be a little sore the next day, but not so sore that you have to put off exercising so you don't hurt yourself.



It sounds like you're both doing a great job; keep it up!



Source(s):



I'm an RN



</answer>

<original file>4926.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk28002.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Ralphy
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 329 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



196 pound male (14 stone), 6ft, with a belly! want to lose weight! ?



Hi, I am starting the gym tommorow.



I am a 23 year old male, 14 stone (196 pounds) and 6ft.



My bmi is slightly into the overweight, however I am increasingly concerned that i am putting on weight. My stomach is an issue as I have gone up a trouser size. And looking at old pictures my face seems much bigger than what it used to be!



Anyway, does anybody have any tips out there? I have lose weight before but i was living on my own then, and was probably down to not eating!



I want to lose the belly and tone up. I am not interested in becoming the next sly stallone, just want to be able to fit my clothes again!



Thanks



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I lost 1.5 stone (21 lb) from 12st to 10.5st (I'm 5 foot 8) last year as my jeans were starting to get a bit tight.



I cut out the starches (bread, potatoes, rice, pasta) and started eating lots of fruits and vegetables and lean meats. I'm not talking about Atkins here, but starches are basically "filler foods" with little nutritional value but lots of calories.
Also, once you cut out the bread, you will be cutting out the butters and fats that go with them, and high calorie sandwiches.



Then do a little exercise every day (A mile or two run should be enough) and the weight will drop off.



Once the weight is off it may be possible to relax the diet a bit (maybe at weekends) and maintain the weight, but you can't go back to old habits or the weight will go straight back on.



Remember it's a change in lifestyle and there are no short term fixes.



Good luck :)



Source(s):



I've done it myself!



</answer>

<question>

lately ive just lost alot of interest in food. i still like what i like, but ive also gone off alot of foods. And also, because my dinner break is at 1.10 pm in the week, im usually past hungry by then, and i dont eat much for breakfast as its too early for me. so im not easting as much as i should be. i used to eat like every hour, but now im getting used to been hungry that its not bothering me that much anymore.



the thing is i am naturally slim, and am one of those people who have to work hard to keep weight on. so this is worrying me now and i wondered if any1 had any tips for how i can figure out eating when my dinner is so late in the day. and why do you think ive gone off a lot of foods?

<answer from>



nitsrek
Member since: 06 August 2006
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Finding the motivation to exercise involves a combination of starting with short workouts (and then lengthening them over time, when your body and mind feel ready), making sure you're doing an exercise you like, and changing up your exercise routine when you get stuck in a rut.



I mainly walk (outdoors), but I do it because I love it. I also do Pilates for the same reason, but I did try a couple of yoga classes to see if I'd like that to; I didn't, so I don't do yoga. I used to do aerobics in the living room, but after five years of it almost everday, I got burned out and moved on to something else. I'm into swimming and tap dancing as well (yep, just get some cheap tap shoes, beginning DVDs, tap mats to tap if you don't already have a good floor, and you're all set), but I know I like them because I've tried them out. That said, I can't stand the gym. Experimentation is the key to finding what you really like.



When I haven't exercised for a while, I make the effort to do something for a minimum of 3 days a week for at least 3 weeks (they say that habits form in 21 days). When I'm on point, I find myself working out for at least 60 minutes/day 5 days a week; but I never beat myself up if I'm not on point, or even if I don't feel like exercising.



Keeping the benefits of exercise in mind is also a motivator. It makes you feel great (especially if your prone to depression), you get your body in shape, and you don't have to starve yourself because you're burning calories (you can't have brownies and pizza everyday, but you know what I mean).



Brainstorm physical activity that you'd find interesting (not what other people tell you is interesting), start slowly with 20-30 min workouts, remind yourself of the benefits, and accept where your body is and what it can do without beating yourself up over it.



And don't forget to have fun!



Source(s):



I've lost over 40 pounds more than once. I'm a regular exerciser who likes to listen to my body



</answer>






<original file>5237.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk28348.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Krista F
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 159 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How is weight lost from the body? ?



I am curious as to how weight is actually lost from the body in a physiological sense. I know what to do to lose it but how does it leave your body?



</question>



<answer from>



heyit'sm...
Member since: 17 March 2008
Total points: 253 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sweat, I guess.



</answer>



<answer from>



ronny_ra...
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Fats, proteins, and carbs are converted into energy by the muscles. This energy then leaves the body mainly in the form of heat (through the maintenance of body temperature) but also in some other forms (sound energy for example).



Remember that energy cannot be made or destroyed, just changed from one form to another.



There are many chemical reactions that take place within the body to allow muscles to convert foods to useable enery. A useful link is here:



http://www.the-fitness-motivator.com/how...



</answer>



<answer from>



E F
Member since: 20 December 2007
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



When you 'lose weight' your body burns fat that has previously been  stored, for energy. It's like raiding the fridge when you're hungry! You need energy, the body raids your fat stores. If we stick with the fridge analogy, when you raid it, it leaves the fridge emptier - your body raids your fat stores, they get smaller.



Fat is metabolised, or burned, when the pancreas releases an enzyme called lipase which breaks down the fat so it can pass through the digestive system and be converted to the energy your body needs.



You can get more info by typing in 'fat metabolism' into any search engine.



</answer>

<question from>



only_me_...

<question>



How do I lose my "belly" and tone up?



I am quite overweight and currently on a diet, however, I would like to achieve a flat stomach. I am not sure what to do first.. lose the weight and then tone up or both at the same time. If I do both at the same time, will my stomach become larger as it will be toning the muscles before I have lost the weight?



</question>



<answer from>



megaloma...
Member since: 29 April 2006
Total points: 21606 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



People always want to overcomplicate it but its really very simple, eat less and exercise more.



Diets don't work.  The best thing is to SLOWLY evolve your diet into making healthier choices.



Same with exercise, slowly increase your exercise amount.  Aerobic exercise (such as walking, running, swimming or x-country skiing) is the best for fat loss.



Resistance training is good for strengthening muscles and can be done at the same time but its not as effective for weight loss.



There is such a thing as muscle 'tone' but for the most part 'toning' is a misunderstood and misrepresented marketing ploy for all the hundreds of sham products out there.



Source(s):



B.G.S. (Kinesiology)



</answer>



<answer from>



Luciana L
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)

Diet & Fitness

<answer>



To achieve what you want you need to change your diet so it is full of low fat and low carb foods and no junk food, sugary foods and drinks.



Then you need to focus on doing cardio exercises at least 3/4 times a week for a minimum of 25 mins.  This will get your body into fat burning mode and will have an effect on the size of your belly.



The toning exercises are good too - The Plank, crunches, scissor kicks etc and you should do those after your cardio but remember that the cardio and diet is where you will get the flat stomach from.  the toning is simply to help define the muscles so don't just do 100 sit ups every night.

http://instantfeelgood.blogspot.com/2008...

<answer from>



girlnext...
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 282 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Using things that are made to work out your abs will not actually give you a flat stomach if you have fat there. It may give you stronger stomach muscles, but they will still be covered in fat.



Do lots and lots of cardio (running, aerobics, biking, swimming, etc.) This will help you drop excess fat. You can also do some weightlifting, because building muscle also helps you drop fat since it uses more of the calories that you take in than fat does.



Once your stomach is a bit smaller, then start with the crunches or anything made to tone the abs. But continue with the cardio work, it's very healthy and will help you drop more weight or at least keep any weight that you've dropped, from coming back.



Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Creative
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>

Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



"The Silent Crippler"
Member since: 26 January 2008
Total points: 528 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How much weight would i gain in 4weeeks...?



if i train 6days a weeek of weights and 1 day rest, plus taking 2 protein shakes aday and eating alot of foood such as lots of protein and carbs eg steak chicken and pasta ect...,
plus any other suggestion would be helpful on weight training



</question>



<answer from>



benw2200
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 882 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all depends on your body type.. some people put on weight like it's nothing and some people can't do it to save their life. I'd say you can expect anywhere from 5-10 pounds, depending on where you are right now.



If you're training 6 days a week make sure you're getting a good split so you don't overtrain your muscles.. for example don't do something involving triceps 3 days in a row, be sure to vary things up and give yourself time to rest. Let your body tell you what to and what not to work.. if your upper body is sore but your schedule has you doing a chest workout, take it really light or take that day off till you recover. The recovery stage is when your muscles actually grow, so if you don't get good rest you will accomplish nothing.



be sure to add abs and core exercises in as well.. too many people weight train like madmen and completely forget stuff like abs.



good luck!



Source(s):



weight training for 4+ years



</answer>



<answer from>



John D
Member since: 03 April 2008
Total points: 540 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only way to know is to try it out, you may put on no weight at all it depends on your metabolism,



</answer>

<question>



WHat is THE best ab workout? need them to be better distance runner?

<answer from>



benw2200
Member since: 02 June 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



you need good abs to be a better distance runner? I was under the impression it was a bit more involved with your legs and cardio :\



Anyway, there is no BEST ab workout.. but there are thousands of variations on basic ones so you can find which one you like best. Google "ab workouts" and you'll get millions of results, most with pics and videos that show you how to do them. My personal favorite exercises are flutter kicks and "full-body" sit-ups done on a bench.

<answer from>



Rice and Peas
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



6 Second Abs, it's a simple machine that clicks 3 times as you go down and 3 times as you go up, doing it in 6 seconds (1 second a click) is supposed to be the best way. You can get them from eBay for around £12, it's basically a crunch machine.



Source(s):



http://www.6secondabs.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



Linda
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 148 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i prefer the bicycle ones.
the one where you have your hands at your temples and you keep on rotating elbow to opposite knee and its continous motion. so your abs never stop working. to raise the level on that, you can use a medicine ball or dumbells.
but you need to work out all areas of your abs to increase stamina and strength. obliques, lower back. the whole core.
back extensions, where you lay face down like superman, but take your hands and put them up on your temples again and while keeping your lower body still and on the ground, lift your upper half of your body off the ground and hold and go back down.



to make it harder you can go up and twist left then right and thats a rlly good lower back core workout.



Source(s):



training experience



</answer>

<category>

</category>



<question from>



Heather M

</question from>



<question>



Underweight,Perfect,Overweight…



i am 12 years old and i am 8st 4lbs and 5ft 2" tall am i the rightweight?



</question>



<answer from>



staciana...
Member since: 20 April 2006
Total points: 408 (Level 2)

Tia K

<answer from>



LittlePr...
Member since: 18 February 2008
Total points: 1869 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You shouldn't lift any weights until the initial pain goes away. You should ice your shoulder now until the swelling goes down.



Work out other parts of your body and cardio.



When you get back to the pool, ice EVERY time you get out.



Ask your coach which exercises you can do outside the pool to help build your muscles in your shoulder. Slowly, low weight.



Source(s):



Had shoulder problems in HS.



</answer>



<answer from>



niffer
Member since: 07 March 2008
Total points: 3458 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You might want to add some push ups for the chest muscles.  The power that you gain will aid in performing explosive moves inside of the pool.  There is also nothing working your back so do some seated rowing on a machine or using the cable pulleys.  When you are doing the bench press ensure that you do the three types (reg, incline, and decline), that way you target all three heads of the chest muscles.



Good Luck!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Danielle spiteri
Member since: 09 May 2008
Total points: 127 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you think you have swimmers shoulder then you should probably see a physio just to make sure...
I personally wouldn't do any exercises that involve using the shoulder, however any core or lower body exercises will be fine.
To overcome this problem it might be worth working with an experienced coach or swimmer to develop a better shoulder roll.



This usually not only helps get rid of the problem, but also makes for a more efficient stroke.



Hope this helps



Danielle Spiteri



</answer>

<question from>



Mark J

</question from>



<question>



Please can i get another workout for my abs to get a six, pack thats effective & not 8 minute abs or couch abs?



</question>



<answer from>



niffer
Member since: 07 March 2008
Total points: 3462 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everyone has a 6 pack it just is usually hidden under the abdominal fat that every person has.  Just ensure that your body fat is low and you will get what you want.



</answer>



<answer from>



tohian
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 2234 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



I recommend these exercises 4 to 5 times per week:



Crunches
Bicycle Crunches
Planks
Side Planks
Torso Twists



Do one set each with 30 seconds rest between exercises. Rest 3 minutes. Repeat. You'll be in agony at the end of the 2nd cycle. As you get better, increase the number of reps per exercise or increase to 3 cycles, keeping rep and rest parameters same.



Finally, you should be getting at least 30 mins of cardio 5x a week to get your body fat down real low. You need to be at least 8% bodyfat for a full 6 pack to show. And you know of course that to do this, you need to be dieting correctly.



Source(s):



I am a nutritionist and trainer.



</answer>

<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



jntmuse
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 169 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Not fat but need muscle tone...exercise tips?



first of all, i am happy with my body, i don't think that i am fat or anything. i am 162cm and 49kg, which is pretty light it's just that i don't have much muscle tone and my stomach isn't tight etc.



is it possible to get a lean, toned muscular body within 2-4 weeks? what exercise would you recommend (eg, how much cardio daily).



help much much appreciated =)



xx



</question>



<answer from>



Bob
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 1070 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, that is too little of time to get into shape. I would give it about 2 months at least. Work out (with weights) On Mon., Wed. and Fri. Do cardio On Tues, Thurs, and Sat. and rest on Sunday. Within two months you will be toned and "ripped".



</answer>



<answer from>



niffer
Member since: 07 March 2008
Total points: 3462 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



In order to gain muscle tone and definition you need to lift weights.  Cardio is only helpful when you want to lose body fat.  I would develop a lifting program that targets specific muscle groups during specific days of the week.



For example,
Monday: bicep, tricep, back
Tuesday: Rest
Wednesday: Legs
Thursday: Rest
Friday: Back & shoulders



All muscles require 24 -48 hours of rest in order to repair the damage that is done by lifting the weights.  Training this way (depending on the weight) should start to produce results in about 3-5 weeks.  This process will not quick fix anything.  It is hard and will take time but the results will be rewarding.  If there was a quick and easy way, don't you think that everyone would look great.



Good Luck!!



Source(s):



Information based on working with a trainer for 9 months now.



</answer>






<original file>8026.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk31447.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



ladybugg...
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 45 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is eating every hour healthier then every 2-3?



i know people say its supposed to speed up your metabolism when you eat 5-6 small meals every 2-3 hours each day rather than 3 big meals. but would it work even more if i ate something small but healthy every hour? i have the time forthis and i wouldnt mind it. i just want to know if it would be as effective. thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



niffer
Member since: 07 March 2008
Total points: 3462 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is such a good question!  Everything I read (articles, research papers, books, etc.) list the standard 2-3 hours.  I think that there is probably a reason for that.  I don't think our digestive systems would be able to process food like that.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bob
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 1070 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Eating every hour is too often. The reason people say to eat every 2 to 3 hours is because your body technically goes into starvation mode after 3 hours and starts eating at your muscles (a catabolic state). For building muscle you need to be in an anabolic state, where you body is building muscle instead of burning it for energy. Eating every 2 to 3 hours also keeps you from over eating when its time to have your main meals (breakfest, lunch and dinner) which will cause you body to store more fat. Stick with 5 to 6 meals a day and you'll do fine; every hour will just make you fat.



</answer>

</category>



<question from>



Sid K
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can you see if i'm overweight?



Can you see if i'm overweight, these are my measurements:
Gender:male
Age:15(16 in 2months)
Height:176cm(5'9'1/2)
Weight:57kg(116-120pounds)
Waist:29 inches(at naval ring circumference)
Hips:33 inches(widest part)
thighs:19'1/2 inches(top most widest part)
calf: 13 inches
Biceps: 11inches(flexed)



I just feel like i'm really overweight and fat.



</question>



<additional details>



It just seems that alot of people in  my class look alot skinnier  then me.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Allison
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You are nowhere NEAR overweight. The average adult man is 5'9" and 190 lbs. The people in your class might appear a lot skinner than you because you are much more grown up than them. You are already taller than the average man, and weigh much less. As you grow older, you will have bigger muscles (as you clearly do) and will overall seem thicker. This does not make you fat, it makes you more of a man than your peers.



Another problem is that it is really hard to get comparison between yourself and those in your class. You can never see yourself from a distance the same way you see them. The view from looking down on the rest of your body, or in a mirror are not accurate. Plus the clothes you wear can drastically effect how you look. You aren't overweight at all, so don't be so hard on yourself. If you are really struggling with that issue, try talking to your school counselor. Talking to your counselor doesn't mean that there is anything wrong with you. They are there to help you deal with things that stress you out such at this.



After you talk to your counselor, you could try eating a more balanced diet and exercising regularly if you are still concerned. The most important part is that you are healthy, not that you are a certain weight. Look at http://www.mypyramid.gov/ for ideas about how much of each food group you should be eating in a day. Eating a balanced diet will ensure that you get all of the vitamins that you need to keep growing and to stay a healthy weight. To build tone that will make you look nice and lean, try joining a sports team at your school or biking or walking around your neighbor hood or a local park a few days a week.



You most definitely are not even close to overweight or fat. You are actually UNDERweight if anything. Try your best to stay healthy, talk to your counselor, and don't compare yourself to others in your class. All of you are growing at that age, some of you faster than others.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

Its really helped me try to indicate how to overcome this problem, I think i'm going to talk to my parents and the school councilor.
I think i'll take your advice and start doing some jogging around my neighborhood.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Anitaa :)
Member since: 12 March 2008
Total points: 414 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



By just looking at it, you're no where near overweight. Since you're tall and you ownly weigh about 57kg. If you're unsure, google "Calculate BMI" and type in your height and weight to find your BMI. If your BMI ranges around 18.5-24.5, you're normal weight.

<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Michelle D
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I need a muscle work out routine, can you help me?



I usually go to classes so I don't make up a routine for myself. I only need an upper body workout as I do other things for my lower body. I will be going to the gym so what machines should I use & how many reps and what not also. I mainly would like to focus on my triceps & and stomach, but wouldn't mind other things either :-) thanks



It is for toning to not muscle gain... if it makes a difference



</question>



<answer from>



Jeff G
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well, I am not totally sure why you are just targeting certain muscles, but if you want someone else's advice, this is what I would say:



Do all the varieties of push ups  (( wide, regular, and Diamond))
Do allot of pull ups----also using different approaches......wide & narrow ,and regular grip.



Put your feet up on a bench, have your arms on another bench behind you, extend all the way down---making a 90 degree angle with your arms, and go back up......repeat this as many times as you can. This is an AWESOME Triceps work out.



Using the Row machine works out the triceps, however its primary purpose is your Lattisimus Dorsi.



I would HIGHLY suggest developing your ENTIRE upper body. Doing only a couple muscle groups will make your upper body look totally out of proportion. I'll take your word for it that you are actually doing your lower body workout, but make sure everything stays in proportion.



Best of wishes!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you



</asker's comment>

<answer>

With the diet of red tea, at a rate of 4 cups per day, it was observed a loss up to 7 pounds in 5 days. This diet is thus an excellent starting point when one starts a diet and should be followed of a balanced diet to ensure the slimming and not to suffer from a yo-yo effect.

<question from>

<question>



Vit B + D +multi and Glucosamine, Can you mix all these vitamins?

<answer>



My sister lost 75 pounds in the course of a year (I'm still working on it), & yes, the skin will sag.  She has resolved this by working on exercises that tone her body.  She loves Gilaad's workout.  She also said Pilates helped a lot.



Hope that helps some!



</answer>



<answer from>



tohian
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 2236 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



Generally, with such a massive amount of weight to lose, some saggy skin is inevitable. I know it's tough to hear but that's usually the case.



One thing your friend can do to minimize this effect is to lose weight VERY gradually, I'm talking about something like 1lb per week. At this rate, the body has time to adapt to the loss in fat mass.



Another thing to do is to build up muscle mass. With some muscle to "fill up" the space left by the lost fat, the skin will appear to sag less. That's why I will normally never agree to take on a client for fat loss if they're unwilling to do weight training. To me, it is absolutely essential to do both.



Other than that I'm really not sure what else can be done. She should consult her doctor for more information about possible surgical intervention if really necessary.



Source(s):



I am a nutritionist and trainer.



</answer>



<answer from>



niffer
Member since: 07 March 2008
Total points: 3480 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Toning the muscles will help to fill the gaps.  See fat occupies more space inside of the body and muscle takes up less space, so gaining muscle will make her look slim but it also helps to fill in some of the void that will be left after losing the fat.  Her skin will sag but the younger you are the more your skin can take.  Also losing weight at the slower rate will allow the skin to spring back into its original shape.



</answer>

<answer from>



Dom S
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 445 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



How to get rid of your "love handles"



1) grab 2 dumbbells of moderate weight
2) stand up with arms at your side
3) bend sideways with legs straight and try to touch the outside of your ankle with the dumbbell
4) return to sneutral position
5) Do the opposite side
6) return to neutral
You have done 1 rep. Now do 9 more and that is 1 set, now do 3 more sets = 4 sets and that is a good "love handle workout"



Inner thighs. Adduction and Abduction



Mostly gym machines are for this but you can get by without it.



1) Grab a "dodge ball" or a half deflated basketball
2) sit down and put it between your thighs
3) press inward with your thighs as far as you can and hold it for 3 sec.
4) return to neutral position
That was 1 rep, do 9 more for 1 set, do 3 more sets for 4 sets and that is a decent workout for your inner thighs



You can also do:



Lay on your side with your hand cradling your head and your legs outstetched and toes poitned
Lift one leg as high as you can and hold it for 3 sec
Slowly drop it back to neutral position
that is 1 rep, do it 9 more, that is 1 set, do it 3 more sets that is 4 sets... NOW flip over to other side and repeat.... That is another good thigh/bun workout.



Also Leg lifts and sit ups will help you as well.  Just remember to do proper form.  WHen doing sit ups NEVER rest your chin against your cchest or interlace your fingers behind your head.  Instead, lift your chin upwards and put your hands at the sides of your head ( this will prevent your natural reaction to want to "pull" your head up when the resistance gets tough"



I hope this helps



Source(s):



ACE Personal Training Certification



</answer>

<answer from>



niffer
Member since: 07 March 2008
Total points: 3488 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why don't you try to pack all of our meals for the next day the night before.  Our bodies require nutrition via food and not liquids.  Liquids break down too fast in the body and you will eat more then you think when you go to eat because you will feel so hungry.  It takes work but the benefits work out in the end.



If you really must eat the shakes and bars ensure that they contain the following:
Shakes: 26g protein, 3g fat or less, 5g of carbs of less
Bars: 20g of fat or less, 20g protein or more, 50g of carbs or less



Not all bars and shakes are truly health.  Some of the bars are worse then eating a snickers or other chocolate bar.



</answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Isa
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 286 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a topic that is widely debated in the health and fitness arenas. The anti-supplement camp says that a person can get all of the nutrients they need by eating a variety of healthy foods in the right proportions. They suggest eating at least 5 servings of fruits and vegetables per day along with enough dairy products, lean protein and whole grains. In their minds the supplement manufacturers are just out to get your money.



The pro-supplement camp, however, says that the produce that is available today is being grown in soil that is increasingly depleted due to over-cultivation and lack of proper rotation techniques and contains far less vitamins and nutrients than it did back in the old days. They claim that you would have to eat way too much food and consume far too many calories to meet your nutrient requirements. I tend to agree and would suggest a good multi-vitamin to most people.



You should seek a vitamin without iron, however, because the ferrous sulfate they use as an iron supplement is difficult to assimilate in the body (especially when taken at the same time as calcium) and adequate iron can be consumed through small portions of lean red meat and green leafy vegetables.



When it comes to all the supplements for weight lifters, there is just as much debate. While some of these supplements have been proven to improve gains slightly, I am not sure the benefits outweigh the costs for most of these types of supplements. Other than maybe taking an amino-acid supplement post workout (a good whey protein shake will have all the amino-acids you need for proper recovery), I would suggest saving your hard earned money for more important things.



What about caffeine? Studies have shown an increase in performance and endurance when taking a caffeine supplement (cola, coffee, green tea or “energy drinks”) before a cardio workout. Another touted “benefit” of caffeine is that it boosts the metabolism. Since your program does not include a cardio workout and you do not want to increase your metabolism (you are burning calories too quickly already), I would strongly advise avoiding caffeine altogether.



Source(s):



http://workout.sylickon.com



</answer>



<answer from>



jobica
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Whey protein is quickly metabolised therefore best taken before a workout. Soy protein is slowly metablised so its best to use a protein that contains both. Fat does not turn into muscle. You need to build muscle in turn to burn body fat. My bf uses herbalife protein shake drink daily and only goes to the gym twice a wk maximum. He says it helps him keep the muscle he has built over the yrs even if he misses a week or so at the gym. I get it from www.naturalw8loss4u.info for him.



</answer>

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Ralfcode...
Member since: 16 April 2006
Total points: 38765 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Odds are, neither one is really right.  Unless they have been calibrated recently, most scales are off by a few pounds.  Home scales are notorious for being inaccurate.  The trick is to find one that is reliably inaccurate.  If one gives you the same weight day after day, or shows a weight gain or loss that is consistent with your exercise and eating habits, use that one to track your weight.



One other thing to consider - always weigh yourself when you're wearing the same type of clothes.  Either wear the same shoes, shirt, pants, etc, or weigh yourself only in your underwear, or something so that you don't have to try to fudge the figure to account for what you're wearing that day.



A quick question - what does a stone weigh?



</answer>



<answer from>



Rachel H
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)

<answer from>



Alive at last...
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 3922 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



Your rate of development will have something to do with being able to produce the look you want.  As far as the "hump", along with the normal bicep exercises try adding the two following movements:

1.  Zottman Curl
This is a normal bicep dumbell curl in the positive direction.  At the top of the curl, turn your palms 180 degrees and finish the negative portion of the curl.

2.  Modification to the Dumbell Curl and Hammer Curls
At the top of the motion (end of the positive motion), add a twisting motion that turns your palms outward.  This will only result in about 45 degrees of twist as you get to the top of the motion but will help in the results you are looking for.

As far as the whey protein, this will not help you build muscle unless you are having problems getting your required protein intake.  It will come in useful postworkout though as you will need both fast burning protein and fast burning carbs as soon as you finish your last rep - at minimum within one hour of your workout.

Good luck!!



</answer>

Dr Frank
Member since: 03 February 2007
Total points: 81396 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Women's Health



Diet & Fitness



Other - Diseases



</answer from>



<answer>



4 stone would require some difficult choices. You would have to chose not one but the two limbs you would miss least and have them removed. Sustained weight loss is usually in the order of 1 to 1  1/2 lbs a week!

The problem with your question is that if you look in "search for questions" it comes up 30 times every day. I have had some criticism for repeatedly using the same answer, but since I am happy with my answer, and the questions are the same, I don't see the issue with recycling the same answer.

In practise for problems that came up on a regular basis we tended to use patient leaflets to avoid having to repeat ourselves this seemed a sensible use of resources. What follows is thus in effect me information leaflet.

Weight loss and fitness is always a long term commitment and never a quick fix. If you really want to reduce your weight a bit, this is a complex regime, that should help, I would get a pencil to write it down, in case you forget any of the intricate details.

Currently only using the criteria 'lose weight' there are 9,419 questions and answers on Answers already. Mis-spell it as 'loose weight' and you get another 2,633! 'Weight loss' will add another 1,883. 'Too fat ' 15,515 and 'overweight' 2,692 and 'over weight' 26,269!!!!!.

'Diet Pills' gives 607, Green tea 482, Hoodia 195, 'pink patch' 119, 'Xenical' 91 'Reductil' 78, 'Slim fast' 215 (and Slimfast 69 ), lipotrim 44 and 'orlistat' 40 . Do you spot a pattern here? OMG that is 60,000 questions with the same basic theme, wanting to lose weight!

Here comes the only answer, no tricks, no pills, no short cuts, If you really want to lose weight, loose weight, not be too fat or overweight, follow these instructions carefully:-

1) Eat less
2) Take regular vigorous exercise

Repeat 1 + 2 forever



Source(s):



GP for more years than I care to remember



</answer>

<question>



HELP i need to get a nice bum?

lets face it,ladies dont like a flat no bum lol

<answer from>



Allie C
Member since: 26 May 2008
Total points: 1517 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



If you are up to it, I suggest buying a video called Butt and Thighs in the Windsor pilates series.



It worked wonders on me! Just do it 5 times a week and within about 10 days you will notice a major difference. But, you do have to pair it with a healthy diet plan.



But, if you are not willing to buy it, you could do 3 sets, 10 reps of squates. 3 sets, 10 reps of plies. (Feet set about 3 feet apart, toes pointing out, and dip like you would if you were doing squates.)  Also, do some lunges, those are good for toning not only your butt and outer thighs, the also target your inner thighs which is something ALL women need to work at.



I hope this was somewhat helpful.

Good luck!



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk35131.txt</current file name>



<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Paul Finch
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 61 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Please i need help!!!! UPPER BODY



hello at the moment i have a multigym and i use it every day......and a lot a day.....

i am trying to build my upper body so i am doing a lot of bench presses.....high weights with low reps......is this right...

i am also doing triceps pull downs and lat pull downs.....at nights i do 200 crunches and around 150 push ups.......

am i doing the right things to build my upper body......mainly pecs...



finally how long will it take to see a difference in my upper body....i can already lift a heavier weights but i cant see a visual difference

all suggestions are welcome



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



...Your training program is retarded. First of all, you shouldn't be working out more than once a day if you want to build mass. You should have short workouts between 45 minutes and an hour. It should be get in...lift...get out while conserving as many calories as you can. Also, its pointless to do the same workout two days in a row. Your muscles need several days to recover. I work one muscle group per day... about 3 - 4 exercises... with no more than 11 heavy sets per day. I take saturday and sunday off to rest.



Plus...pushups are not going to do anything for mass. They might tone you up a bit but theyre not going to build muscle. I would save the calories and not do them unless you do a few good ones as a warm before your workout.

You  should be lifting heavy enough that you can only do 6 reps at the most per set.



Eat lots of calories and lots of protein.



</answer>

<answer from>



aaronbro...
Member since: 17 April 2007
Total points: 913 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not enough protein here AT ALL... as well, too much in the way of simple carbs.  Here's my feedback:

Breakfast - Nesquik is garbage - that has to go.  Too much bread, that's 600 calories in bread alone for breakfast.  Switch to a fibre/whole grain cereal with your milk.  Drop the honey and eat a banana instead.

Lunch - Vegetable soup is good if the sodium is low.  Spaghetti with seafood can make or break you.  If you have creamy sauces and white pasta, the heathiness will be sacrificed.  Keep the soup, and switch the pasta to a salad with a lean protein or a stirfry.  A brown rice dish works really well for lunch as well.  Another easy solution is to eat burgers with the lettuce as the bun.

Dinner - I don't really see any substance food here... just sort of random stuff thrown together.  Again, toast is unneeded.  Carrots aren't the best choice of vegetable.  Grape juice not needed.  Make a stirfry or salad (depending on which one you had for lunch) with a different type of protein from lunch, some fresh veggies, and a healthy sauce.



</answer>

Sarah M

<answer>



Nothing is happening because nothing works!
I don't know how many times I've answered this question now, but seriously, no sports work, stretching or hanging off trees, drinking milk - nothing.
You might grow naturally with a few more years of age but that is purely because of your DNA, which you cannot change.
You can't stimulate the growth of your bone structure to increase height, it's impossible, how would it work? 
The only thing you can do is improve health and density of your bones.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AkCQiBmAD3YNTAnaB_cuUpSxBwx0822.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk35917.txt</current file name>



<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



SÉAMUS!!...
Member since: 07 June 2006
Total points: 1765 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Does stretching develop muscles?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Stretching before and after each workout helps to prevent soreness and become more flexible.  However, aggressive stretching can actually HURT the muscle.  So no, it doesn't develop the muscle.



Source(s):



http://www.muscle-body.com/questions/doe...
http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles...
http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/stretch...



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



In what way? Stretching is stretching! Its not going to lead to increased muslce mass like weight lifting does. Its generally good for flexibility and suppleness, as well as stress relief. Tension headaches are caused by tight, tense muslce, stretching can releive the knots and tension and relax the mucles.



</answer>

<answer>



No only weight-bearing exercise develops muscles. Stretching may help your flexibility and stop injuries, but it wont make your muscles bigger.



</answer>

<question>

<answer>



You need more speed less weights, in other words weights will NOT make you lose weight in fact they can add it, you need fast and cardio, bike or treadmill or anything that lifts your pulse/ heart rate. Look at The Worlds Strongest Man, strong as an Ox but as heavy as a double decker.
 Five pounds of muscle will weigh the same as five pounds of fat but the fat will take take up more space, so if you are carrying 150 lbs of fat you would be a lot bigger than if you were carrying 150 lbs of muscle.

<answer>



its very hard to build lean muscle and burn fat at the same time. a lot of bodybuilders and dieteers will go through a loading season (usually fall, winter) where they focus just on eating a lot and gaining strength and muscle mass and not really worrying about fat. then when spring rolls along, they start doing more cardio which will shed that fat, and they will have that muscle. when you do cardio, it burns fat, and unfortunately muscle. get it?



</answer>



<answer from>



ranger_c...
Member since: 06 February 2007
Total points: 8614 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Muscle and Fat weigh exactly the same. One kilo of muscle weighs exactly the same as one kilo of fat. Think about it, a kilo of anything wieghs exactly a kilo.



Fat does have more mass than muscle. That is why a kilo of fat is larger than a kilo of muscle. It is like comparing a pillow weighing one kilo to a rock weighing one kilo. The pillow if fluffy and much larger than a rock of equal weight.

Weight training usually will make you loose inches off of your belly, butt and legs, but not make you loose weight. 
You will weigh approximately the same, but develop a better physical shape and become stronger.

It takes 90 days of weight training to get into shape. It won't happen over night so don't become discouraged.



</answer>



<answer from>



Alex Costa
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 295 (Level 2)

<answer>



Well its more than just an exercise (and a ab lounge which is a waste of money) to get a 6 pack...

Eat right.
This means no Taco Bell, Wendy's, McDonald's, Pizza Hut, or fried things.
Do eat the good stuff, obviously, fruits, veggies. Chicken, Lean beef (or for a better alternative turkey meat. Tastes just like beef. Turkey burgers, Turkey meat sauce spaghetti, etc..)

Drink Right.
This means no soda, juices, beer. Don't waste calories on liquids.
Do drink the good stuff, water... period. For a little vest throw in a lemon. And if you must get drunk, drink liquor, less calories. Try to stick with clear liquor. The darker the color the more byproducts that are produced.

Stay active.
Tennis is good. Play some basketball, workout, swim, swim, swim, run, go dancing.
http://www.caloriecontrol.org/exercalc.h... &lt;-- A fun website that calculates colories burned in lots and lots of activities.

http://www.customizedworkouts.com BUT for your exercise go to this website... They have a ton of ab routines. It's free to sign up and you can download your workouts to your ipod and it'll play video and instruct on how to do the exercise.

good luck

Good luck



</answer>

<answer from>



Stephen E
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 147 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You haven't given us a diet plan.  A diet plan would include a calorie count.



You can lose weight without exercise because in the end, weight loss is about using more calories than you eat.  Eating less than you need, forcing the body to use fat.

But exercise IS a great thing to do while you are dieting, forcing the body to lose fat not bone or muscle too.  A good cardio exercise should get your heart rate elevated for at least 20 to 30 minutes.  And you should include some strength training several times a week.  I like to alternate so that I'm not doing the same exercise two days in a row.  Your body needs some down time, some rest time in there somewhere.  Don't run every day.  Spend 20 or 30 minutes doing some mat-core muscle exercises or some other form of strength exercises using bands, free weights, home gyms, etc.

Did you know your body loses more calories when it's resting than during the exercise time of your day?  Most of your calories will be lost when you are sleeping, sitting, etc.  So do those strength training, weights, bands, core exercise types of things so you can build your muscle mass and burn more calories when your body is at rest.

By the way, every day you should be getting at least TWO dairy.  Say 1% milk or low fat yogurt.  Also you should get some starch.  Whole grain breads, cooked cereal, whole grain pasta.  And you need healthy fat...something like smart balance on your bread, Olive Oil, fish oil pills.  Your Protein should be lean such as low fat cottage cheese for breakfast.  Skinless turkey, chicken, lean pork, fish, etc. And if you are going to diet take some multi vitamins so you don't deprive yourself of nutrition.  Salad?  Use dark greens.  Lots to learn, I suggest you read up on eating healthy and avoid diets that try to cut out carbs, protein, etc.



Eat your dairy, Starch, Fruit, Vegetable, Protein, and healthy fats and multi-vitamins.  Don't fall for a fad diet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Joshua G
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)

healthy weight chart (females only)
5'0"=100lbs
5'1"=105lbs
5'2"=110lbs
5'3"=115lbs
5'4"=120lbs
5'5"=125lbs
5'6"=130lbs
5'7"=135lbs
5'8"=140lbs
5'9"=145lbs
(this weight chart gives a healthy weight to height ratio according to a BMI scale and even gives a few pounds to spare)

<question>



Why do I feel more hungry mid morning if I eat breakfast rather than if I dont?



I thought eating breakfast was supposed to stop you feeling hungry but it doesnt work for me



</question>



<answer from>



brilock1
Member since: 27 July 2006
Total points: 3469 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you dont eat breakfast your body thinks that it is not getting any food that day and so starts to use your body fats. I would assume that continues during the morning and therefore you are not hungry during that proccess?



</answer>



<answer from>



uci
Member since: 11 September 2006
Total points: 670 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



maybe your body require more at the mid morning.. or maybe you load your stomach too much in the morning..n when your stomach was emptied..you'll feel hungry..
i'm not really sure.. but the fact is.. you will feel hungry when your body needs food..it's physiological and psychological controlled..



</answer>



<answer from>



billy
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 87 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its your metabolism. When you don't eat in the morning your metabolism puts you into a minor starvation mode and slows way down thus you won't be hungry for longer. When you do eat in the morning it speeds your metabolism up to where it burns fats much quicker, so you will naturally be hungry quicker. thats why they say to eat 4 or 5 small meals throughout they day. It speeds up your metabolism and makes u much healthier.



</answer>



<answer from>



Nuf said
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 2561 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



when there's food in your stomach, it produces stomach acids to break the food down. When your breakfast (usually small, even worse if it's cereal) has been broken down, you have all this stomach acid that you normally wouldn't have. this is what make you feel peckish, as opposed to feeling properly starving.. ie it's your stomach that feels hungry not your brain.

..and i say cereal is worse because milk is alkaline and so takes even more acid to break down



</answer>



<answer from>



mickey
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



Psychic P
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why would you want to work out for 5 hours? unless if its because you are practicing for some sort of activity (eg: sports meet, marathon, the olympics) Anyways, if you lose an average of 300calories per hour, that would mean that you can lose up to 1500 for the five hours of exercise.



If your body needs at least 1600calories a day to work (this is excluding ANY sort of activity, only bodily/organ functions) then you can eat about 3100calories a day without GAINING or LOSING weight. It will be the same.



If you want to lose the weight, cut back on 500 calories if possible.



The point it, dont eat too much if you want to lose weight.



</answer>

<answer from>



Dr Frank
Member since: 03 February 2007
Total points: 81396 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Women's Health



Diet & Fitness



Other - Diseases



</answer from>



<answer>



The problem with your question is that if you look in "search for questions" it comes up 30 times every day. I have had some criticism for repeatedly using the same answer, but since I am happy with my answer, and the questions are the same, I don't see the issue with recycling the same answer.

In practise for problems that came up on a regular basis we tended to use patient leaflets to avoid having to repeat ourselves this seemed a sensible use of resources. What follows is thus in effect me information leaflet.

Weight loss and fitness is always a long term commitment and never a quick fix. If you really want to reduce your weight a bit, this is a complex regime, that should help, I would get a pencil to write it down, in case you forget any of the intricate details.

Currently only using the criteria 'lose weight' there are 9,419 questions and answers on Answers already. Mis-spell it as 'loose weight' and you get another 2,633! 'Weight loss' will add another 1,883. 'Too fat ' 15,515 and 'overweight' 2,692 and 'over weight' 26,269!!!!!.

'Diet Pills' gives 607, Green tea 482, Hoodia 195, 'pink patch' 119, 'Xenical' 91 'Reductil' 78, 'Slim fast' 215 (and Slimfast 69 ), lipotrim 44 and 'orlistat' 40 . Do you spot a pattern here? OMG that is 60,000 questions with the same basic theme, wanting to lose weight!

Here comes the only answer, no tricks, no pills, no short cuts, If you really want to lose weight, loose weight, not be too fat or overweight, follow these instructions carefully:-

1) Eat less
2) Take regular vigorous exercise

Repeat 1 + 2 forever



Source(s):



GP for more years than I care to remember



</answer>



<answer from>



supplies...
Member since: 19 December 2005
Total points: 343 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I highly suggest the 6 Week Body Makeover, it is a life changing experience. My husband and I started it at the end of June my husband has lost 22lbs and I have lost 15lbs. It has a great support team, plus you get support on-line in forums and in chat-rooms. I have learned so much since I have started the 6WBMO. I also thought well I have 30 days to return it so I'll try it. There is no way I would return this program, I knew that after the first week when I started seeing results. My husband has not been this low in weight in over 8 years. We tried other diets, we exercised, nothing was working.
This does!!



</answer>

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If i was you i would find a bmi calculator on the internet. just type bmi calculator into google and ti should come up 
They give you a rough idea of how overweight you are.

tip
the best way to lose weight is a balanced and healthy diet fresh fruit and no snacks 
and when you go to the gym run for about 20 minutes and then walk for 40 minutes. Walking burns more calories than running, (it's to do with your optimum heart rate) and the tone up with small weights

<answer>



I am afraid you are not going to lose weight without going to any personal effort. Hypnotherapy specifically, comes out no better for weight loss than it does as an aid to smoking cessation, scoring no better than placebo. I am afraid with a hopeless attitude like that to weight loss, you are just going to join the desperately doomed!

The problem with your question is that if you look in "search for questions" it comes up 30 times every day. I have had some criticism for repeatedly using the same answer, but since I am happy with my answer, and the questions are the same, I don't see the issue with recycling the same answer.

In practise for problems that came up on a regular basis we tended to use patient leaflets to avoid having to repeat ourselves this seemed a sensible use of resources. What follows is thus in effect me information leaflet.

Weight loss and fitness is always a long term commitment and never a quick fix. If you really want to reduce your weight a bit, this is a complex regime, that should help, I would get a pencil to write it down, in case you forget any of the intricate details.

Currently only using the criteria 'lose weight' there are 9,419 questions and answers on Answers already. Mis-spell it as 'loose weight' and you get another 2,633! 'Weight loss' will add another 1,883. 'Too fat ' 15,515 and 'overweight' 2,692 and 'over weight' 26,269!!!!!.

'Diet Pills' gives 607, Green tea 482, Hoodia 195, 'pink patch' 119, 'Xenical' 91 'Reductil' 78, 'Slim fast' 215 (and Slimfast 69 ), lipotrim 44 and 'orlistat' 40 . Do you spot a pattern here? OMG that is 60,000 questions with the same basic theme, wanting to lose weight!

Here comes the only answer, no tricks, no pills, no short cuts, If you really want to lose weight, loose weight, not be too fat or overweight, follow these instructions carefully:-

1) Eat less
2) Take regular vigorous exercise

Repeat 1 + 2 forever



Source(s):



GP for more years than I care to remember



</answer>

Sorry, honey, you are incredibly overweight. The normal weight for a person your age and height is about 120.



For breakfast: one bowl of cereal should be enough.
Mid morning snack: granola bar.
Lunch: A sandwich, apple and Ziploc bag of low-fat chips.
Afternoon snack: a banana.
Dinner: A piece of chicken, a scoopful of rice and a scoopful of vegetables. No dessert.

You should exercise for an hour each day, intensively. And don't just take my advice: GO AND SEE A DOCTOR IMMEDIATELY. This is grossly overweight and could create health problems for the rest of your life.

<answer>



13 is very young to be worrying about guys liking you and having cellulite.  What you need is a good healthy diet and an exercise regime.  The best thing you can do is go to a personal trainer, dietitian or doctor who can write you a good diet and tell you what exercise would be best to help you lose weight.  Just not eating doesn't work because you just get ill and have to eat again and that makes the weight come piling back on.  It's a good idea to eat load and loads of vegetables because they are low in calories and high in nutritional value.  Running is probably the best exercise you can do to lose weight.  If you ran for 30 minutes a day everyday you'd notice a big change in a couple of months.
It's best to get advice from some sort of fitness professional to get the most out of your diet and exercise.

<answer>



If your BMI is between 30 and 39.9 you're obese. This means you're well over the ideal weight for your height. This could cause serious health problems and affect your life expectancy.



Are you eating more than the recommended amount of calories per day? Are you getting enough exercise? Once you gain the confidence to start exercising regularly you'll notice a huge difference.

Speak with your GP for advice if you've tried to lose weight without success. 
As part of a healthy well-balanced diet, cut down on salt and alcohol. Try to eat more fresh fruit and vegetables. Also, eat smaller portions at mealtimes and avoid snacking between meals.



This is no reason for you to try and starve yourself as it could affect your health worse.
Also try and eat more soup and drink plenty of water, as this bloats the stomach, making you feel more full and less hungry,

Good luck, and a guy will like you for who you are, not what you look like :o)



</answer>
