<answer from>



Ally
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 980 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



AVOID dieting and restricting calories. Also? don't fall for gimmicks, such as magic diet pills, crazy weight loss devices, and other expensive and useless things. You can easily lose weight by starting to do more cardio exercise, and of course eating healthier on a daily basis.



-Definitely get into an exercising routine, and try to find something that you enjoy! If you're in school, definitely try to join a sport - even if you think you won't like it. Sports will give you the excuse to exercise nearly every day, and it can also be fun & interesting & you can meet new friends.
-Drink water. Water is ESSENTIAL for you & your body - and definitely does help with losing weight. Water gives you minerals, increases circulation, and of course suppresses your appetite. Try to drink water (or 100% juice) instead of pop, coffee, or any other carbonated beverage. Water's definitely better for you.
-Change one small eating habit at a time; take it week by week. Start eating more fruits during the first week, eat more veggies the second, switch your milk from whole to skim the third, etc. Making small changes over time will definitely help you more in the long run than trying (& failing) at dieting.
Good luck =]



</answer>

<answer from>



azulpali...
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Since you are young, you have the blessing of a youthful metabolism.  Once you start a sensible eating / activity plan, you should be able to return to a more healthy weight quickly.  I've personally found that having feedback really helps me keep on top of my diet.  I'm using a web based calorie / exercise tracking tool.



So whenever I eat something, I immediately log it.  When I do activities, I log it also.  I get to see my caloric intake/burn for the day.  It helps to see how many calories you're taking in daily.  The website is: http://www.livestrong.com/thedailyplate



They also have a lot of foods listed so you can immediately determine calories for something you're eating.  If you can't find what you're eating, you can input it yourself manually.  I've been using this tool, and I've already lost 10 pounds.  Remember that slow and steady wins the race.  Use whatever tools work best for you.



</answer>

<question>



Am I Wierd Or Am I OK?



I skip breakfast and lunch all the time and only eat a cookie or two until supper... *sigh* I can't stop, though, because I am, like, NEVER hungry...I always have high levels of energy, though and am the brightest person in class (...or so they say...) and well, very athletic for a person who's not interested in sports. Well, I just don't think I have a very normal lifestyle, yet it's so hard to change. I mean, who else do you know that barely eats, yet is the most energetic and brightest (...with MY class, it's not hard, lol...) girl in her class!? Ugh... I don't even know what I'm trying to ask... umm... How can I change, I guess...?



</question>



<additional details>



And I am at a healthy weight of 95 Lbs. I'm 5"3.



</additional details>



<answer from>



The Last Harlequin
Member since: 09 April 2008
Total points: 4500 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I do this sometimes (when I'm mad at myself for binging) but I don't feel good afterwards. I don't have any energy and my heart speeds up. Plus I get dizzy.



I don't recommend it. It's not very healthy and it will slow down your metabolism. Please try to eat something! I don't want you to get hurt! You're one of my bestest contacts and friends on here! ♥



When you eat breakfast, it wakes your body up and you'll burn the calories by lunch. For breakfast just eat a little (don't STUFF yourself)! Start off with half of a banana or a Quaker Oatmeal Breakfast Cookie (they are good for you, and also tasty!) until you develope hunger. Once you start eating regularly at a fixed time your body will get hungry. Peanut butter on toast with a little honey drizzled on top is also good.



For lunch, try Smucker's Uncrustables. They are tiny little pockets (white bread) filled with either grilled cheese, peanut butter and honey, peanut butter and grape, or peanut butter and strawberry jelly. They are snack-sized, so maybe an apple or some trail mix with it if you can. Then as you start to get hungry after training your body to eat lunch, you can go for full-sized sandwhiches if you can't do that now.



Also, tend to eat your snacks / junk food during the day and NOT after dinner. Your body burns the most calories during the day, so that way you can eat and not regret it.



Good luck, and please take care! Try what I said - if you think you have energy now, just wait! It'll be like stuffing you with hyper-active sugar pills! XD And who doesn't enjoy hyper energy?



Source(s):



TTYL ♥



</answer>

<answer>



You are messing with your metabolism and it's going to bite you in the a** eventually.  This bad habit can lead you right down the road to diabetes, thyroid disease and many other metabolic disorders.  Your 'lots of energy' is like the state when someone is hyper due to being over tired.  It's very stressful on your body.  I was the same way as a teenager and just didn't eat until supper, even into my 20s.  It catches up with you.



If you want to change, try to plan out what you will eat in advance.  When I don't do this, I go completely off track.  Try to have nutritious snacks like fruit and just graze during the day, without having meals.  You'll feel more normal if you aren't used to eating at that time.



My co workers now tell me to 'GO EAT'.  You could also try powerbars, having smoothies for breakfast and protien shakes.  Maybe you have some people who support you and can do the same?



</answer>

<answer from>



Antonio D
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 865 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The fat in Ice Cream comes from the cream...Low Fat ice cream is ice cream with the Milk fat or cream removed or reduced (ie. Low fat milk)...Same thing with milk ... 1%



2%...that's the Cream/fat content...What you need to look at is...The Total Calories of the Ice Cream and the Calories from Fat...All Food labels should have this information...Simple math divide the two to get a percentage of Calories from fat...foods over 20% is not recommended or at least limit the amount you eat...this is only a rule of thumb ...as some food maybe a high percentage in fat..but it's good fat...ie. Nuts...Good Luck



</answer>

Source(s):



http://howtoloseweightbyme.blogspot.com/...



</answer>



<answer from>



arun ice

<answer>



Take lemon juice on morning when you get up its good for health too you may lose your weight slower with no side effects

<answer from>



Ally
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 957 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



some ideas:



-start exercising more often.



-drink more water (8 glasses a day!).



-walk or bike to the places that you'd normally bus or be driven to.



-try to eat less junk food, and eat more fruits & veggies.



-be creative & learn to like healthy cooking! experiment with recipes. try to get your family involved with your goal of healthy eating.
-become a vegetarian.
-join a sport with school! (not only is this a good way to get a workout in, but who knows? you could really like a sport & not even know it yet!)
quit drinking pop(soda) or any kind of carbonated beverage. (this means diet, regular, most flavored waters, etc.) instead, drink water or 100% fruit juice!
-try to eat balanced meals instead of skipping meals & eating one big meal. this will help speed up your metabolism, which will make you lose weight. =]
-don't weigh yourself often! we often think we've gained weight when really, it's just fluctuating due to water weight & bloating. so if the scale tells you something you don't want to hear - don't freak out. use how you feel, and how you look as a measurement of how healthy/thin you are becoming.
-don't stress over it. you're 13 - your body has so many changes to go through yet (it sounds corny, but it's true), and as you get older - you'll naturally lose some of your baby fat as you go through puberty. so, really, don't stress too much over this.



and honestly, don't even worry about dieting or restricting calories - just try to recognize your unhealthy habits & change them for the better. good luck! =]



</answer>



<answer from>



Riley J
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 134 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<question>



What are some simple exercises? ?



i recently broke both my ankles (dont ask), so my movement is very limited for the next few months.



my cousins husband told me he gained 15-20 pounds when he broke his ankle, so im trying to avoid this.



been doing sit ups, the one where you lay on your back and fold your body in half. kind of like toe touches..... but on your back, and the one where you run, but on your back. like your riding a invisible bike upside down.



these are killing my back though. any other ideas would be really appreciated. maybe some kind of in place cardio.



i also thought of getting a wheel chair, but i live in mountain terrain so its some what impossible to get around in one



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



lie on the floor. now holding on to a chair raise both legs straight up in the air now swing them down until they are about 5cm from the ground. Repeat 10 times and do 3 sets. you can do this with a friend instead of a chair by grabbing your friends ankles.



another thing you can do is lie on the floor then raise your legs and oretend your riding a stationery bike in the air.



</answer>

<question>



Which foods are 400 calories or less ?



I'm doing this halloween fast and today I must eat 400 calories. problem is my fridge is practically empty so I'm wondering what I must buy. what I do have in my fridge is tomatoes, apples, bananas, special k,brown bread,margarine and traditional food. what must I eat!

<answer from>



persepho...
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 479 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



buy bread (not this flabby toast but one of a bakery) and soup. That should do it.



or make a salad. or you can do a fruit salad with your apples and bananas.



</answer>



<answer from>



high school senior
Member since: 16 November 2007
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You really shouldn't fast. It's an unhealthy way to lose weight and you'll just end up gaining the pounds back. You can still lose weight just by eating 1,280-1,800 calories (depending on exercise) instead of the normal daily value of 2,200-2,500.



Skim milk has the full calcium of milk and is usually 60+ calories less. Yogurt is a good source as well.
Vegetables that you can eat as a snack (baby carrots, edamame, celery, etc.) are good and low caloric.
Just a handful of raw nuts (walnuts, almonds, pine nuts, etc.) can keep you full.



</answer>

<original file>4259.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk52946.txt</current file name>




<category>



Health



Diet & Fitness



</category>



<question from>



Jane R
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



DIET SCHEDULE please!h?



heyy i'd really appreciate a diet schedule! Im got a bad knee and cant do much excersize for a long time at once so i just need a food one!
Thanks alot!



</question>



<answer from>



Jarohn
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 199 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



DIET SCHEDULE



MONDAY-SUNDAY



Morning: Avoid High GI foods such as cornflakes, waffles anything with sugar. Have a coffee and an apple if possible.



Lunch: Low GI foods such as fish, legumes, pasta. Try making a sandwich with vegetables such as lettuce, tomato, ham, cheese, eggs etc.



Dinner: Make a salad or cook up some red meat or chicken. Try to eat as much poultry as possible to balance out your diet.



Supper: Treat yourself with a snack such as dairy dessert, but not too high in sugar.



Stick to this plan and you'll lose weight at the same time. Good Luck!



</answer>

Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 786 (Level 2)

lunch: wholemeal with lean meat and salad, tuna, egg salad (this is high in cholesterol so you should not have this to often) wrap, sushi, rice paper roll, stirfry, veggi pizza with not much cheese.



afternoon tea: same as morning tea but not as much



dinner:pasta, stirfry, veggi soup, noodles, and heaps more

ok so i've wanted to lose weight for ages so i've tried this new thing where i dont eat at all until 4.00 pm the whole day no breakfast nuffin and it is seriosuly working with amazing results is it bad?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, very bad for you.  Starving your body makes it go into fat storing mode, so once you do eat, all that food is stored as fat.



There's no easy way...diet, exercise and persistence.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



You would lose more if you ate nothing after four pm and had breakfast and dinner to be honest



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Is may work right now, but it's not good for you and you may gain more weight later. When you don't eat when you're hungry, your body stores whatever it does get as fat because it doesn't know when it will get food again. You will hold on to your food longer, and your metabolism will slow down. When you do decide to eat something really bad or eat more again, you will actually gain weight and it will be harder to lose because of your metabolism. Just find a way to exercise regularly and eat several small healthy meals a day and you will lose it the right way and keep it off. Good luck!



Source(s):



Physical therapist



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is bad, it's not healthy.



What I suggest is... go to the gym everyday. Or go jogging, whichever you prefer. In order to lose weight healthily, you have to take that pain. Pain is good, it means you're working yourself and trust me it does work. Try doing a mile and a half on the treadmill (2.4), record your time, and next time, try to beat that.
Eat breakfast, lunch, and fruit in between. You don't have to cut out sugar completely, after a work out treat yourself to some chocolate. If you were working out hard enough you would have lost the calories from that choc already.
Then obviously keep having small meals until about 9/10pm.



good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, it is bad. Starvation diets can have a terrible effect on your body as well as diet pills. 95% of all people who try fad diets and starvation techniques will gain all of that weight back in a year or two. Here are some of the lesser known side effects of this kind of diet:



* Weight gain.
* Depression.
* Food cravings.
* Feeling tired and listless.
* Constant hunger.
* Reduced interest in sex.
* Chronic fatigue.
* Hypothyroidism.
* Hormone imbalance.
* Scaly skin or eczema.
* Premature wrinkling of the skin.
* Dandruff or dull, lifeless hair.
* Mood swings.
* Chronic yeast infections.
* Poor immune system- frequent colds or respiratory illnesses.
* Digestive problems.



Click below to learn more about diet and the three reasons why diets fail.



Source(s):



You On A Diet. . .  Again
http://aiminghigher.blogspot.com/2008/01...



Why Diets Fail
http://aiminghigher.blogspot.com/2007/12...



Is Your Scale Broken?
http://aiminghigher.blogspot.com/2008/08...



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's what I found on line.



One answer
One meal a day is not enough to keep a person going. After a while, the body resists, goes into starvation mode, and holds on to body fat. If you want to lose weight and avoid yo-yo dieting, you should eat small meals throughout the day. This will improve your metabolism.
An additional answer
I am a Muslim. We fast in Ramadan. We wake up to have a meal before sunrise (which could be 3-4 o'clock in the morning), and don't eat all day, not even water until sunset (this can vary from 4 o'clock in winter to 9 o'clock in summer - like now). Last Ramadan started towards the end of September and lasted for one month. I lost one whole stone (14 pounds) that month from eating only one meal in the evening. Now its June, and have since put it back on because of eating burgers and crisps and chocolates and other junk. I will be started to eat one meal in the evening again tomorrow to lose the weight again. Healthy meals obviously.
Exercise helps. If you burn off 800 calories during the day when you are not eating, (I do this by jumping rope for 1 hour) and have a 300-400 calories meal - which is enough to fill you up in the evening. You have burned 400 excess calories that day, which add up over a week and help the weight come off. Of course, you can burn more calories and lose more weight.
An additional answer
Eating one meal per day will slow down your metabolism and eat away lean muscle mass. If you lose lean muscle instead of body fat, this will radically slow down your ability to lose weight in the future. Eating only one meal per day is also likely to encourage you eat junk food. By eating small frequent healthy meals and exercising, you will improve your metabolism and create lean muscle mass. Lean muscle in turn, further increases your metabolic rate.
Additional Answer
I've done both ways. I've lost weight the 'proper way' eating the 5-6 meals and working out like a fiend at the gym. As some have mentioned you will only have weight loss, when you calories burned, exceeds calories consumed. However, recently over 5 yrs of not having time for the gym, packed on 50lbs. And balloned up to 225. I tried the unhealthy approach of one meal a day, using coffee as my boost during the morning and day, and eating a sensible lunch. Heck even some of the dinners were not sensible. Me being a steak fanatic, I've had some monster porterhouses.
Now this said, I DID lose a lot of weight in a short time. In 30 days, I lost 35 pounds!! and for the most part my main exercise was brisk walking 3 miles. Some days twice. So for someone to say, a one day a meal doesn't work is wrong. If you have the luxury of time and the money for a gym membership, you can do it the 'correct way' and lost the same weight over 6 months or longer.
Admittedly, one day a meal is not for the weak willed. I think the big win for me, was going back to the mind set I had when I worked out, that eating was a function(boo-hoo, do I hear a chef crying), and not to be savored and enjoyed everytime with a greasy cheeseburger. And my dinner meals are ususally pretty moderate. Even try the subway thing on occassion, perhaps I'll be the next Jared.
Also, one last note, again to the naysayers testament. There are some moments durnig the diet, when I would have a cocktail or two at night to knock out early to ease the stomach pangs. And some of the walking sessions, were tough. But the body is amazing, it can adjust. Now I'm in the process of slowly upping the calories, to a maintenance phase. So far so good. No weight gain.
An additional answer
Well, I was going to try only eating once a day, but thanks to the answers that said DONT DO IT grabed my attention. I know when to listen, and I thank you for that. It just makes sence that the metabolism will slow down, and maybe I will get fatter. NO WAY! I only have 20 pounds to lose and I will try eating 5 to 6 meals a day and exercise and green tea. thanks again
An additional answer
In the long term, eating one meal per day will slow down your metabolism. This will make it much harder for you to lose weight in the future.
To lose excess body fat and to increase your metabolism, eat a meal about every three waking hours (5 or 6 meals per day). You will not be eating more food; you will simply be spreading it throughout the day. Each of those five or six feedings should contain at least 15 grams of unprocessed protein (from natural sources) for a female or at least 20 grams per feeding for a male.
This one change alone will speed up your metabolism and help to curb food cravings.
You can do more to boost your metabolism besides eating well.
For example, proper strength training will increase lean muscle. Lean muscle is your metabolic furnace that will burn extra energy (calories) 24 hours a day. Similarly, brisk walking for several miles daily will burn extra calories during and immediately after walks.



Source(s):



http://wiki.answers.com/Q/Can_you_lose_w...



</answer>

<question>



(Colonix Program by DrNatura.com ) Is it really effective? and Would I benefit from it?



I've read a lot of things about this Colon program.  Most people seem to like it. But I wanna hear opinions and hopefully opinions from people who may have tried this already.  I need some input from People I KNOW are real.



Please and thank you, I appreciate any info



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



From what I've heard, most doctors say the same thing:



Our bodies are designed to function properly. They are designed to cleanse out toxins and keep our colons clean. Any "one-off" health solution like this (diets, colon cleansings, etc.) are designed to make money. If you REALLY want to keep your colon clean and your body running well, eat healthily, drink lots of water, and make sure you consume enough fiber every day.



If you still have questions, ask your doctor.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Imagine my surprise to come across a question about a product I've personally used.  I bought the Colonix colon cleanse program in addition to an herbal supplement that replenishes the local flora in your digestive system once you're done cleaning everything out.  A coworker of mine was constantly going on and on about his quarterly colon cleanses and some people swear by them.  I believe what the first guy said in part because I think when people eat the right stuff our bodies stay healthy but after years of putting the wrong stuff in it takes a really long time to get it out with help.



When you consider for a moment the things I saw coming out of my body when I used this product I would have to say that this is more than just a money maker.  My recommendation is that you do two rounds of Colonix if this is your first time and you're over thirty.  If you're not over thirty or close to it then you should be okay with just one round.  It's been almost a year since I used the product so I'm probably a little off on the amount in the containers you get but I'm pretty sure you get enough to do two courses should you wish to repeat the process.



The important thing is to follow the directions exactly and not make any substitutions to the treatment.  You might want to add a vitamin supplement if you're not taking one but don't detract from the program...and don't forget the tea.  Don't microwave the tea pouch IN the water...heat the water up and THEN add your tea bad and let it steep.  The longer it steeps the stronger it gets...but let it go for about five minutes...and squeeze out the water from the bags.  You won't regret it...it's very effective.



</answer>

<answer>



To lose weight you just have to eat healthy (lots of fruit and veg, 3 meals a day, snack of healthy foods if hungry) and do about an hours of exercise a day.
To maintain your weight eat about 1500 - 2000 calories (no more) and exercise about 3 times a week at least.
Hope that helps a bit.

<question>



What should my weight loss goal be?



13
5''4
140 lbs.
i want to set a goal but i don't know what it should be.
when could that goal be met?



</question>



<answer from>



Krystle
Member since: 07 May 2006
Total points: 1934 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well no one on this site can give you a proper answer for that because none of us know your body type. BMI is not accurrate so we can't base it off of that. It depends on your body type, percentage of body fat, how much muscle you have, and what you want.
DO NOT make a particular weight to be a goal because if you are doing exercises your fat and muscles proportions will change and muscle weights more then fat.
I suggest that you find out your body fat percentage and set your goal to be in a healthy body fat range. Everyone has a different bone structure and amount of muscle so a weight to height can't work because everyone is built differently. I am 5 ft 5in and 160 lb andthing less then 145lb would not be practical for me because of my body type where as someone my exact same height and weight looks much heavier then I am. THere are even people that weight less then me that look heavier then me or more then me that look less them me. SO height to weight is not the answer.
Make sure you are eating a proper diet but don't debribe yourself of the things you like because then you will binge. Get some cardio activity in. Since you are young weight training is a not a very good idea so you are better off with calestetics (push ups, crunches, leg lifts, ect.) You can find many of them on different websites.
Your goal should be to look and feel fit and healthy and the suggestions above will help you to achieve that. You can feel free to contact me at any time and I can go further into details with you.



</answer>

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



beachgir...
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 4744 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



As a rule of thumb (not taking into account age, sex, lean muscle mass, etc.), your ideal weight can be determined by multiplying your inches over five feet by five and adding 100.  So, in your case, 4 times 5 = 20 + 100 = 120 as a goal weight.



Don't use a time factor for your goal.  Because you only need to lose 20 pounds, make "eating healthy" your goal and shoot for one pound a week.  Do this by cutting about 250 calories out of your diet each day and burning off another 250 calories through exercise (daily walks, bike rides, etc.).  If you do this and lose the weight this way, it will stay off and you will learn healthy habits for life which will help ensure that you don't have chronic weight problems.  When you set a time factor, you're setting yourself up for disappointment and failure.  Your body will lose the weight in it's own natural time with your assistance.



This page can help you learn what "eating healthy" is all about.  Good luck!
http://www.easy-weightloss-tips.com/eat-...



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 06 January 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)

The main thing is she drinks soda instead of water.  Stick to water and you'll be fine.  Remember, health foods rock in the end!

<answer>



One way to get rid of your fatigure is to stay hydrated. Make sure to drink something before, during, and after workout. Also, are you eating anything before workout? Your body will need certain carbs for energy. You need a mix of simple and complex carbs before, and simple carbs after a workout. Your simple carbs would be something like fruit, something with sugar, or baked potato. Complex carbs would be like cereal, toast, something like that. These tips should surely help get rid of your fatigue.



Also, sometimes listening to music while working out can help motivate you to keep on going.

<answer from>



BeatDrop...
Member since: 04 November 2007
Total points: 1004 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



you seem to just be doing mainly arm exercises- this is why you are fatiguing quicker than planned. you are supposed to mix it up, for example you seem to be doing circuit training so start with one set of dumbells, then do sit ups, then squats, then go back to arms. if you keep up working the same muscles over and over the lactic acid will consume alot more than hoped (this is what increases the rate of fatigue). so basically, mix it up, that way you can fit more in!



</answer>

<answer from>



samsmart...
Member since: 22 April 2006
Total points: 321 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everyone likes a small waist! Whether it's the 'hourglass' for women, or the 'V' for men, it involves  tapering at the waist.
For the chest- used to pull the arm in at the shoulder: pec flyes,  the benchpress(incline, flat and decline) and the pushup must be included.
The back has 2 main muscles, which, if exercise, will exercise all the other muscles as well.
The lats (latissimus dorsi)- Used to pull the arms down, pull back with hands at navel level. Do pullups, bent-over rows, 1-arm dumbell rows, dips.
Traps(trapezius)- Used to retract, lift or depress the shoulder blades.
Especially retract, so focus on rowing at chest level e.g upright row, high cable row,reverse flye.
Overhead/military presses are good too.
For waist, crunches, planks and swiss-ball rotations work well.
Good luck!



</answer>

Member since: 30 September 2008

<question from>



Joe D

Total points: 3708 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



Other - Society & Culture



</question from>



<question>



Is it bad that i ate cake after my workout.?



i had a protein shake w/ 30g worth of protein and 1/2 banana in water/ice then on the side i had a lil bit of cake w/ a good amount of frosting on it it was goood =) and i couldnt resist so i figured post workout is an okay time to have it te sugars used to fuel my muscles right? or is it a bad thing im not gonna do it everyday but like just this time or would it be okay to have after workouts like sugar type stuff.? if im getting the craving thatd be the best time w/ some whey no?



</question>



<additional details>



welll does glycoen or w/e it's called get depleted if i had a really big carb meal before a workout? like it seems like no matter wat my glycocen stores are gonna be depleted after a workout right?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Yamster
Member since: 10 August 2008
Total points: 4101 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Nope, not bad at all.  What have I always been telling you? Lol.  Upon awakening and post-workout are two times of day glycogen is depleted from the muscles and liver, so insulin spikes caused by rapid rising in blood sugar levels will cause glycogen to be stored in the liver and muscle, as opposed to adipose tissue.



This is because as long as the muscles and liver are not sufficient in glycogen deposits, that is where glycogen will be stored.  If you want to have "bad" carbohydrates, post-workout and upon awakening are the time to do it.  The carbohydrates are needed to replenish glycogen depleted from the muscles and liver to bring up energy levels again.



Edit: The sugars from carbohydrates is the same, carbohydrates all break down to glucose.  It is only the source of the carbohydrates that can differ.  After a workout, the carbohydrates from cake are fine.  Unless the muscles and liver already have sufficient glycogen, the glucose gets stored as glycogen in the muscles and liver.



If not, the glucose gets stored as glycogen in adipose tissue.  After a workout glycogen from the muscles and liver is depleted, so it is essentially fine to consume carbohydrates from cake post-workout.  The downside is that there are other ingredients that aren't too healthy in cake, but it is negligible if you eat junk food now and then.



Edit: If the meal had a really large amount of carbohydrates then glycogen was still depleted from the muscles and liver (although not as much as if you weren't to have a high carb meal pre-workout), so your muscles and liver still probably didn't have as much glycogen as they should, so the cake should be fine.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks for the info and well what's done is done it was good too =) but still i think ill go w/ a diff source next time like some bananas milk and whey



</asker's comment>

kid1000

Of course you wouldn't want to do this everyday but if you're lifting heavy and have it it's not gonna make a difference.

<question from>



Catastro...
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What are foods that people think are healthy, but they're not?



Well.
I want to diet.
and heaps of people eat the wrong foods because they don't know enough about them.
I know that muesli bars are terrible for you even though people think they're good because they have muesli and fruit in them.
anyone know of anymore really BAD foods to eat?
Help?



</question>



<additional details>



So Freemale do you think it's bad for me to be juicing like 5 apples and 2 carrots and drinking it?



I was under the impression it was good for you :/



But I guess they are lots different to smoothies.



and thanku everyone! (:



</additional details>



<answer from>



Freemale
Member since: 30 April 2007
Total points: 734 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



As someone else said, most natural foods consumed in moderation are healthy.  Most food bars are junk in that they have too many carbs/sugar or the protein is made from collagen which our bodies don't absorb well when consumed.  Additionally, lots of low fat foods
substitute sugar for taste, so the decrease in fat/calories is deceptive compared to what effect they have on fat storage.



One issue to consider is nutrient density.  Many cereals are touted as heart healthy because they have little to no saturated fat & they contain fiber.  Problem is, most of the cereals manufactured by Post, Kellogg's, & other brands are loaded with sugar, which itself is not heart healthy.  The meager amount of fiber doesn't negate the sugar content (each gram of fiber blunts 1 gram of other types of carbohydrates, such that your body secretes slightly less insulin- which can be a fat storing hormone).  Likewise, bagels & muffins aren't that healthy compared to other sources of fiber.  Fruits with equivalent caloric/carbohydrate content would offer more nutrition via phytochemicals that fight cancer & such.



With that said, fruits can be unhealthy when consumed in *massive* smoothies.  We can't physically eat as much liquid as we can swallow.  Additionally, liquid carbs are absorbed twice as quickly as solid carbs, causing a more rapid insulin spike (increasing the likelihood that they will be stored as fat).



The best things tend to be the closest ones to their naturally occurring state.



------
To add to what has been written, yes, I think having 5 apples (22 grams of carbs per medium apple) & 2 carrots (8 grams each) would be too many carbs for most people in a single sitting.  Altogether, that would be 126 g of carbs, which could act like much more in its juice state.  That's over a third of the RDA for carbs (300 g) from a single smoothie.  Good nutrients in those foods, but too many carbs (& perhaps fiber) in a single shot, possibly contributing to diarrhea & consequent malabsorption of what you just consumed.  If you exercised intensely, you might be able to handle around 60-80 carbs in post workout meal without gaining fat.



Here's a good start: a hand sized portion of meat (assuming you're not vegetarian), a medium apple, & a 7 in carrot or hand sized equivalent of broccoli crowns would be a balanced meal.  That would give you adequate protein, fat, carbs, fiber, plus a multitude of vitamins, minerals, & phytochemicals.  Never consume carbs on their own; always eat them with protein & fat.  Balance your meals to include sufficient sizes from every food group.



There are portion strategies that can help you without putting in much effort.  Instead of 3 meals a day, you could break them into 5 small meals a day, getting the same nutritional benefit while lowering the likelihood of storing some of the calories as fat.  This lowers overall insulin secretion & makes it work more efficiently.



Shopping in the right sections of the store can give you good food ideas.  The periphery of the store generally has the best real foods (fruits, vegetables, meat, chicken, fish, cheese, yogurt, etc.).



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<answer from>



mz_dazed
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a great question. Soy is probably number 1 on the list. What they don't tell you is that soy beans contain goitrogens which MUST be fermented before eating. Asian countries eat fermented soy foods like tempeh and miso and they eat roughly two teaspoons of soy per day not truck loads as we all think. Plus they also eat a lot of ocean foods like fish and seaweed which contain iodine . This would counterbalance the suppressant effect on the thyroid. The thyroid of course controls our metabolism and our ability to burn calories!



Low fat foods are unhealthy. Your body has a great need for saturated fat and cholesterol and contrary to popular belief there is actually no documented studies out there that prove the correlation between saturated fats and cholesterol to heart disease.
Regarding weight, if you go to the supermarket, you will notice a whole array of low or no fat foods but all the DIET foods contain no carbohydrates or sugar. This is because sugar which also comes from carbohydrates is turned into fat at a faster rate than any other macronutrient (protein and fats). The food industry is well aware of the fact that fatty foods are NOT the culprits. All farm animals are fed only grains for a few weeks before slaughter to fatten them up. Pigs given skim milk as opposed to whole milk will get fat.



Cholesterol is vital! Without it you die and when levels drop low enough you get sick. Our livers have an enzyme which controls the rate of cholesterol production by our bodies. Meaning, if we halve our intake of cholesterol containing foods, our liver senses this drop and immediately increases the production of cholesterol by our bodies. The more cholesterol containing foods one eats, the less the body has to produce and vice versa.



Cholesterol lowering drugs (statins) work by blocking this enzyme so when you lower your food intake of cholesterol, your body is unable to produce the rest that is needed and this results in lower blood levels which evidently causes a false security of lowering your risk of heart disease.



Too much fruit. The fruits these days are all hybrids and bred for size and sugar content only. Most fruits are picked unripe when their nutrient contents are low and are then later gassed to ripen them. Also, fruits contain a sugar called fructose which is metabolised differently than other sugars. It is sent straight to the liver where, if not immediately burned for energy will turn straight into FAT!. This is well documented. Look it up search fructose/dangers/fat...and you will find quotes like this:



"Research from the National Institute on Aging (NIA) in Baltimore, Maryland, shows fructose is more lipogenic (fat forming) than any other sugar or starch. "



Low Carb diets. Also not very healthy. If carbohydrates are restricted to a low enough level the body produces ketones which makes the body very acidic which is what happens to diabectics when they overshoot their insulin requirements. This is an emergency. Ketones are produced as a result of incomplete fat burning and are used by the central nervous system as a "back-up" fuel when sugar levels are low. You are not actually burning fat, because sugar is needed to completely burn fat for energy in cells. This is a fact.



Keep it simple and have everything in moderation. Even alcohol. Don't vilify the fats and know that eating them won't make you fat. I believe its the other way around actually.



Source(s):



www.thincs.org  An association of scientists, science writers, physicians, and other academically trained individuals who are skeptical to the cholesterol hypothesis .



www.westonaprice.org Great Site!



www.westonaprice.org/mythstruths/mtsoy...



www.ravnskov.nu/cholesterol.htm



www.thegreatcholesterolcon.com



www.cholesterol-and-health.com



</answer>

<answer from>



wenzilbe...
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 260 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Diet alone won't get you results. If you really want to lose this much weight in very little time then I'm afraid the weight loss boot camp is the way to go...



But if you feel that your workouts is enough, then a low carbohydrates, and high protein diet is usually the way to go and have fruits or yogurt for snacks so you'll maximize your metabolism.



Also, try to never miss breakfast. Imagine your body is a car, for it to run it needs gas. Our bodies need fuel to burn those calories. If you skip breakfast (1st meal) then your body won't have enough fuel through the day to burn calories. How is it important? Imagine our metabolism is an ice cream cone - the type that has a tip on the bottom. Our metabolism is exactly like it. Our metabolism is at highest in the morning and eventually slows down as the day ends. You need to take advantage of that by providing your body enough fuel to burn stored calories when your metabolism is at its highest (in the morning).



You see a lot of healthy grains in people's diet because it makes you feel fuller longer so you don't eat much. It also helps to cleanse the body - thus making people more likely to go to the toilet more than those who don't eat them.



Oh, and probably the most important thing is to drink LOTS and LOTS of water everyday (lay off the pop, alcohol, and anything you get in fast food restaurants). Sometimes, we are just thirsty and we mistake thirst for being hungry then we eat more when we have to.



Also, keep away from diet pills. Some just increases your heart rate so you burn calories faster even when standing still .. that's dangerous as some cases could lead to heart failures and such.



Keep in mind that what I've said are just tips. They're not guidelines. Checking with your doctor first though would be more responsible. Good Luck  and I hope you achieve your goals. Take care!



</answer>



<answer from>



Tik P
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>

and u ll find tips and weight lose recipes
to loose weight easily

<question from>



sgipo2

Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Weight training - muscular hypertrophy?



ive determined the sets, reps and weight i should be working at, however i would like to know
- how long a workout session should go for and how many times a week it should be done
- how many muscle groups can be worked on in a workout session



thanks for your help



</question>



<answer from>



Tony F
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 150 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



For a fast easy workout schedule go to http://www.firsttimelifter.com This site has everything you need. It breaks it all down. Trust me I made it! Print out the workout I put there. O and when your done click an ad for me so I make like 50 cents. A mans gotta eat. lol Good Luck



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks good webiste
appreciate both other answers too



thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



krieger
Member since: 10 August 2008
Total points: 1568 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



I'd agree with Bobz for session time (~45min; the quicker the harder, therefore better) and times to work a muscle group per week (~2-3; need 36-72 hours of rest), but I have to disagree with muscle groups per session.



Split training works, granted, but is needlessly complicated for most people. You have to be careful you arn't doubling up on a muscle group (e.g.: monday- chest, tuesday- triceps/shoulders =BAD) and you need to visit the gym just about every day. Doing a total body workout 3 days a week is equally effective, and just simpler. You can easily complete a good total body session in about 45minutes. If you're spending much more time then that, you just arn't working hard enough.



Again, they both work, so pick the one that works best for your temperament and schedule.



Source(s):



UBC Human Kinetics undergrad.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bobz
Member since: 14 June 2007
Total points: 161 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all depends on your body type, but the best work out for an average person should take 30-45 minutes, and you should do it at least 3 times a week. I would not hit more than 2 groups together. For example :



Back+ Chest  / Legs + Shoulders / biceps + triceps.



</answer>

<answer from>



Rosemary B
Member since: 02 December 2006
Total points: 366 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I struggle with gaining weight too. In order to gain weight you need to eat 5 to 6 times a day and increase your calories.



It takes 3500 calories to gain 1 pound. Your friend should try adding an extra 300 - 500 calories per day and she needs to take it slow. This usually adds about 1-2 pounds per week. When she sees that she's not gaining weight anymore, she needs to increase the calories again by 300-500 per day.  Keep doing this until she's at the weight she wants.



It's also important to incorporate some kind of physical activity. It doesn't have to be strenuous, she needs more strength and resistance training, not too much cardio.



If she's already eating 3 meals a day, she can add a couple of snacks. And don't listen to all the dieters out there. When someone needs to gain weight they also need to increase their fat intake. Not junk food but healthy food. Nuts are a great source of healthy fats and protein and so is red meat. Shakes and smoothies are good too!



A dietician/nutritionist once told me to eat all the food that overweight people cannot eat but do it in moderation.



Hope this helps.



p.s. Drink whole milk, not skim or 2%.



</answer>

<answer>



First off, don't over do your exercising, or else you'll get weaker instead of stronger. Be sure to eat more healthy foods and less junk food, that will help your muscles get the proper nutrients they need. <category>



Health

</category>



<question from>



awww yeah- that's right!
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 2424 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What can i do to make a treadmill or elliptical read the correct calories for me?



i know that both machines will be off- just wanted to kow how i can make them more accurate



</question>



<answer from>



chris_ki...
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 264 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Find yourself a personal heart rate monitor, it comes with a chest band, to record the information and then sends it to a wrist watch.



Most decent brand heart rate monitors can also transfer the information onto the display of the machine you are using.



You know this will be accurate because you program you stats into the watch before hand, so it knows your body type and age, then by reading your heart rate will calculate exactly the amount of calories burned.



Source(s):



I have a Polar f55 heart rate monitor and it does this, plus im a personal trainer



</answer>



<asker's comment>



very informative! thank you!



</asker's comment>

<asker's comment>



tahanks, but idk what to start eating??



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Ryan
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 247 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Healthy weight loss tips
http://weightlossweightloss.blogspot.com...



Strength training and aerobic exercise --Aerobic exercise burns a lot of calories, Strength training increases metabolism by increasing lean muscle mass which helps in long term weight loss.



Eat fruits and vegetables --Increase your intake of fiber rich foods
They are low in calories but high in fiber. Fiber is digested slower, keeps us feeling fuller longer



Eat breakfast everyday --



Eat smaller, more frequent meals--



Replace white rice, bread, and pasta with brown rice and whole-grain products--



Drink more water--Water suppresses the appetite naturally and helps the body metabolize stored fat.



Increase your protein intake--Protein makes us feel full. It is also important in replacing and building muscle tissue. More muscles burn more fat. It helps to increase your metabolism - which burns calories.



Do not skip meals--Skipping meals makes you hungry which you tend to compensate by eating a lot later.



Spice up your food--Spices boosts metabolism, suppresses appetite, reduce fat absorption



Eat Negative calorie food --Negative calorie foods are foods, which use more calories to digest than the calories the foods actually contain.



Take the stairs and park your car further away from the shops--



Eat slowly--Chewing your food longer will help prevent you from over eating.



Cut down the sugar intake---



Interval Training - great way to boost metabolism--
Tips to stop food cravings



http://weightlossweightloss.blogspot.com...
Boost metabolism
http://weightlossweightloss.blogspot.com...
http://weightlossweightloss.blogspot.com...



</answer>
